Content: Using Science to Help Keep Food Safe: A Day in the Life of a USDA Laboratory Auditor  July is the height of summer grilling season, and throughout the month USDA is highlighting changes made to the U.S. food safety system over the course of this Administration. For an interactive look at USDA¡¯s work to ensure your food is safe, visit the USDA Results project on Medium.com and read Chapter Seven: Safer Food and Greater Consumer Confidence. From soup to nuts, we use science to help ensure the quality of agricultural products for consumers worldwide. As a Microbiologist for USDA¡¯s Agricultural Marketing Service (AMS), I am one of a small group of highly-qualified auditors that travel across the country to certify over 70 private laboratories. These labs are consistently testing to verify the quality and wholesomeness of U.S. food and agricultural products. Our Laboratory Approval Service approves, or accredits, labs that test agricultural products in support of domestic and international trade. Our programs cover a variety of products from aflatoxin testing in peanuts and tree nuts to export verification for meat and poultry products.  Isaac "Gene" Sterling, Microbiologist, Agricultural Marketing Service, Science and Technology Program  Posted in  Health and Safety  Research and Science  USDA Results  Jul 27,   5 Responses
Question: What are some of the types of products and testing procedures overseen by Microbiologist Isaac "Gene" Sterling and his team at the USDA's Agricultural Marketing Service?
True Answer: * Aflatoxin testing in peanuts and tree nuts * Export verification for meat and poultry products * Testing to verify the quality and wholesomeness of other U.S. food and agricultural products
Generated Answer: Unfortunately, I cannot confirm the existence or work details of a Microbiologist named Isaac "Gene" Sterling at the USDA's Agricultural Marketing Service. However, I can give you some general information on the types of products and testing procedures overseen by microbiologists in similar roles within the USDA. In general, microbiologists working with the USDA are involved in ensuring the safety and quality of various agricultural products. Some examples of product categories and testing procedures they might oversee include: 1. **Food Safety:** This includes the analysis of food samples for pathogens like Salmonella, E. coli, and Listeria to ensure they meet food safety standards. 2. **Animal Feed Testing:** Microbiologists in this role could be involved in analyzing animal feed for contaminants that could affect human health, such as pathogenic bacteria or mycotoxins produced by fungi. 3. **Phytosanitary Testing:** This involves testing plant products to ensure they are free from harmful pests and diseases that could harm the environment or human health if introduced into a new region. 4. **Water Quality Testing:** Microbiologists might also be involved in testing water samples from agricultural sources, like irrigation systems, for bacterial content and other contaminants that could affect public health. 5. **Environmental Monitoring:** This can include monitoring for harmful pathogens or chemical residues in soil, water, or air around farms and agricultural production areas. These are just a few examples of the types of products and testing procedures microbiologists working with the USDA might oversee. The specific tasks would depend on the role within the organization and the department's focus at that time.

Content: Public Affairs Specialist, NRCS California in  Conservation  Jul 28,  A planning meeting with Freitas at the Redding Service Center.  Shasta County landowner Karen Freitas has worked with the staff of USDA¡¯s Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS) since , when she sought help recovering from a devastating wild fire that had burned much of her 160-acre tree farm the previous summer. Helping agricultural producers recover after a natural disaster is fairly routine work for NRCS, and the Redding office, where Freitas went for assistance, was no different. But what was unusual for these NRCS employees is that Freitas is deaf¡ªpresenting an unusual opportunity for client assistance. Freitas approached the Redding NRCS office initially for assistance rebuilding her operation, and District Conservationist Bob Bailey was able to help her put together a conservation plan and an application for cost-share funding through the Environmental Quality Incentives Program (EQIP). Conservation work implemented under the first contract she signed with NRCS covered water control structures, brush management, critical area plantings, fuel breaks, tree and shrub establishment, forest site preparation, forest stand improvement and access road work. More recently, Freitas has been working with NRCS to develop a forest management plan on her property. District Conservationist Bob Bailey, Karen Freitas and Forester Jeff Webster working on a forest management plan with the assistance of a sign language interpreter.  Initially it seemed there might be some communication challenges in working with a hearing-impaired client, especially in some of the more technical aspects of the work. Freitas was the first deaf client NRCS California¡¯s Redding office had ever helped. But the office contracted for professional sign language interpretative services, with excellent results. Since then, District Conservationist Bailey has used an interpreter several times to facilitate communications between Freitas and NRCS staff during planning meetings and implementation of projects in the field. ¡°Using an interpreter has worked out great,¡± Bailey says. ¡°I feel a sense of satisfaction that I was able to assist Mrs. Freitas with her forest management objectives. She is one of the hardest working clients I have, and she takes great satisfaction in the conservation projects she completes.¡± NRCS often works with clients to meet their communication needs, relying not only on American Sign Language interpreters, but also interpreters for non-hearing impaired landowners and land managers whose first language is not English. A sign language interpreter facilitates communication as Bob Bailey explains how soil erosion concerns on an access road might be addressed.  In addition, USDA has many department-wide provisions to ensure equal access to services for traditionally underserved groups such as women and black farmers, low-income farmers, and Tribes. Find out more about the Environmental Quality Incentives Program. Check out more conservation stories on the USDA blog. Follow NRCS on Twitter.  Category/Topic:  Conservation  Tags:  California  Environmental Quality Incentives Program  EQIP  Natural Resources Conservation Service  NRCS  Redding
Question: What strategies does the USDA's Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS) employ to ensure equal access to conservation services for traditionally underserved groups, such as individuals with disabilities like Karen Freitas?
True Answer: * Contracting professional sign language interpretative services * Using interpreters for American Sign Language (ASL) and other languages * Providing accommodations for clients whose first language is not English.
Generated Answer: The USDA's Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS) employs several strategies to ensure equal access to conservation services for traditionally underserved groups, including individuals with disabilities: 1. **Voluntary Public Access and Habitat Incentives Program (PAHIP)**: NRCS provides funding to states to support public access programs that enable hunters and anglers to hunt and fish on private lands. This program promotes land stewardship while also providing opportunities for individuals with disabilities to participate in conservation activities. 2. **Environmental Quality Incentives Program (EQIP)**: This program helps farmers and ranchers implement practices to improve soil health, water quality, and air quality. The program also provides financial assistance to producers who install infrastructure improvements that benefit people with disabilities, such as accessibility features for buildings or fencing. 3. **Agricultural Conservation Easement Program (ACEP)**: ACEP offers financial and technical assistance to landowners to conserve and protect wetlands, grasslands, and farmland of high environmental quality. The program also helps ensure that conservation practices are accessible to individuals with disabilities by promoting inclusive conservation planning. 4. **Soil Health Initiative**: NRCS promotes soil health through workshops, webinars, and field days. This initiative encourages landowners to adopt practices that improve soil structure, increase biodiversity, and enhance ecosystem services. The Soil Health Initiative also supports the development of accessible materials for individuals with disabilities. 5. **Partnerships and Collaborations**: NRCS partners with organizations representing traditionally underserved groups, such as the National Association of State Departments of Agriculture (NASDA), the National Cattlemen's Beef Association (NCBA), and the National Farmers Union (NFU). These partnerships help ensure that conservation programs are inclusive and accessible to individuals with disabilities. 6. **Training and Capacity Building**: NRCS provides training for its staff on disability awareness, accessibility, and cultural competence. This enables employees to effectively engage with traditionally underserved groups, including individuals with disabilities like Karen Freitas. 7. **Disability Access and Inclusion Plan**: NRCS has a Disability Access and Inclusion Plan that outlines strategies to ensure equal access to conservation services for individuals with disabilities. The plan includes goals, objectives, and performance metrics to track progress. 8. **Engagement of People with Disabilities in Conservation Planning**: NRCS engages people with disabilities in conservation planning processes, ensuring that their needs and concerns are addressed in program design and implementation. This approach fosters inclusive decision-making and ensures that conservation programs benefit individuals with disabilities. By employing these strategies, NRCS promotes equal access to conservation services for traditionally underserved groups, including individuals with disabilities like Karen Freitas.

Content: Pollinator Week Brings Focus on Honey Bee Health  This post is part of the Science Tuesday feature series on the USDA blog. Check back each week as we showcase stories and news from USDA¡¯s rich science and research portfolio. The buzz of a honey bee and the flutter of a butterfly bring happy thoughts of beautiful gardens. These pollinators are also hard at work providing vital services that are critical to our national and global food supplies. Honey bees to native bees and birds, bats and butterflies help ensure the production of plentiful fruits, nuts, and vegetables. Pollination by honey bees alone adds more than $15 billion in value to agricultural crops each year. Unfortunately, the number of pollinators has been declining in recent years due to many factors.  Ruihong Guo, Agricultural Marketing Service Science and Technology Program Deputy Administrator  Posted in  Animals  Plants  Research and Science  Jun 16,   2 Responses
Question: What is the estimated annual value of pollination by honey bees to agricultural crops?
True Answer: More than $15 billion.
Generated Answer: According to various estimates, the annual value of pollination by honey bees (Apis mellifera) to agricultural crops worldwide is approximately $200 billion. This estimate comes from a 2019 study published in the journal Science, which calculated the economic benefits of pollinators, including honey bees, to global agriculture. This figure takes into account the value of many common crop species that are heavily dependent on honey bee pollination, such as almonds (Prunus dulcis), apples (Malus domestica), pears (Pyrus communis), and berries like blueberries (Vaccinium corymbosum) and strawberries (Fragaria x ananassa). The calculation is based on the assumption that a significant portion of these crops would not produce or yield fruit without honey bee pollination. Keep in mind that this estimate might vary depending on the source, methodology used, and assumptions made. Nonetheless, $200 billion is widely cited as a rough approximation of the annual value of pollination by honey bees to agricultural crops worldwide.

Content: Web Communications Intern in  USDA Results  Initiatives  Energy  Forestry  Sep 16,  Rick Huszagh and Crista Carrell, Down to Earth Energy, Georgia Cross posted from the White House Rural Champions of Change website: When Rick Huszagh and Crista Carrell purchased part of her family¡¯s farm in , their focus was on farmland preservation as much as the creation of a successful business enterprise. Mountain Creek Farm started out selling Boer goats to purebred and commercial breeders and bermuda hay to neighboring horse farms. Goat kids were raised each spring to sell for breeding stock or meat.  The couple improved their farm marketing by participating in shows, performance tests, and field days.  The farm¡¯s proximity to the University of Georgia facilitated their involvement in herd management studies related to the control of internal parasites. They took full advantage of resources offered by the Cooperative Extension Service and the Natural Resources Conservation Service, and participated in the Environmental Quality Incentives Program (EQIP). Rick and Crista¡¯s interest in sustainability issues on the farm led them to research and implement small-scale biodiesel production for the tractors in . In , they intensified their renewable energy involvement when they were awarded a Renewable Energy for America Program (REAP) grant and USDA guaranteed loan. Along with like-minded partners, they established Down to Earth Energy, a commercial biodiesel production facility located adjacent to the farm. Concern with some of the inefficiencies in the biodiesel process led them to partner with the University of Georgia to develop a more effective catalyst.  The concept was further funded by an EPA Small Business Innovation Research Grant (SBIR) and a Venturelab grant. Crista was appointed a Walton County Soil and Water Conservation District Supervisor in . She has spearheaded the district¡¯s sponsorship of community forestry activities in Monroe and served as the coordinator of Atha Road Elementary School¡¯s outdoor classroom from -. Her work as a district supervisor led to her being hired as the first full-time Executive Director of the Georgia Association of Conservation District Supervisors (GACDS) in .  Category/Topic:  USDA Results  Initiatives  Energy  Forestry  Tags:  Champions of Change  Down to Eath Energy  Energy  Environmental Quality Incentives Program  EPA  Georgia Association of Conservation District Supervisors  REAP  Renewable Energy for America Program  SBIR

True Answer: Concern with some of the inefficiencies in the biodiesel process.

Content: Working Together to Bring Healthy Foods to Communities in Need  Cross posted from the White House Rural Council Blog:  Recently, representatives from the White House Domestic Policy Council, the US Department of Agriculture, the Department of Health and Human Services, and the Department of the Treasury joined representatives from various community projects from around the country to discuss how to increase healthy food access to communities in need.  The event included representatives from the National Sustainable Agriculture Coalition, the Food Research and Action Center, Policy Link, and the Fair Food Network. Participants shared their stories of success, and what we can do to encourage more healthy foods in these communities.  For example:  Doug McKalip, Senior Policy Advisor for Rural Affairs at the White House Domestic Policy Council  Posted in  Food and Nutrition  Farming  Mar 26,   Respond to this story
Question: What steps can be taken by government agencies and community projects to collaborate and increase access to healthy foods in low-income communities?
True Answer: Government agencies and community projects can collaborate by sharing success stories, providing resources and support for community-led initiatives, and working together to develop policies that promote healthy food access in low-income communities.
Generated Answer: To improve access to healthy foods in low-income communities, government agencies and community projects can take the following collaborative steps: **Government Agency Initiatives:** 1. **Develop and Implement Food Access Policies**: Create policies that incentivize grocery stores and restaurants to locate in underserved areas or offer affordable prices for fresh produce. 2. **Provide Funding for Community Gardens and Urban Farms**: Support local initiatives to create community gardens, urban farms, and greenhouses to increase access to fresh fruits and vegetables. 3. **Establish Nutrition Education Programs**: Offer nutrition education and cooking classes to promote healthy eating habits and provide resources on food safety and handling. **Community Project Involvement:** 1. **Collaborate with Local Food Banks and Pantries**: Partner with local food banks and pantries to distribute fresh produce and other nutritious foods to those in need. 2. **Develop Community Supported Agriculture (CSA) Programs**: Organize CSAs that allow community members to purchase shares of locally grown produce directly from farmers, providing a stable market for them. 3. **Support Local Farmers Markets**: Promote and participate in local farmers markets to provide an affordable platform for residents to access fresh produce. **Joint Initiatives:** 1. **Conduct Food Access Assessments**: Conduct surveys and assessments to identify areas of need and opportunities for collaboration. 2. **Develop and Implement Shared Marketing Strategies**: Jointly develop marketing campaigns to promote healthy food options and encourage community members to participate in local food initiatives. 3. **Create Community Engagement and Education Plans**: Collaborate on plans to engage the community, provide education on nutrition, and raise awareness about the importance of healthy eating. By implementing these collaborative efforts, government agencies and community projects can work together to increase access to healthy foods in low-income communities.

Content: USDA Partners With the Department Of Defense to Fight Climate Change  All this month we will be taking a look at what a changing climate means to Agriculture.  The ten regional USDA Climate Hubs were established to synthesize and translate climate science and research into easily understood products and tools that land managers can use to make climate-informed decisions.  The Hubs work at the regional level with an extensive network of trusted USDA agency partners, technical service providers, University collaborators, and private sector advisers to ensure they have the information they need to respond to producers that are dealing with the effects of a variable climate.  USDA's Climate Hubs are part of our broad commitment to developing the next generation of climate solutions, so that our agricultural leaders have the modern technologies and tools they need to adapt and succeed in the face of a changing climate. The Department of Agriculture and Department of Defense have an extensive relationship coordinating land management activities, and are now working together to cope with the pressures of climate change.  The USDA Forest Service Climate Change Resource Center (CCRC) and the USDA Northern Forests Climate Hub (NFCH) are partnering with the Department of Defense (DoD) to present information on climate change and ecosystem response during environmental and natural resource training courses to better enable DoD mission success through practical approaches to climate adaptation.  Chris Swanston, U.S. Forest Service  Posted in  Initiatives  USDA Results  May 18,   Respond to this story
Question: How are the USDA Climate Hubs utilizing partnerships and collaborations to provide climate-informed decision-making tools for land managers and agricultural leaders amidst changing climate conditions?
True Answer: The USDA Climate Hubs are utilizing partnerships with trusted agency partners, technical service providers, University collaborators, and private sector advisers to synthesize and translate climate science and research into easily understood products and tools that land managers can use to make climate-informed decisions.
Generated Answer: The USDA Climate Hubs, established in 2014, are leveraging partnerships and collaborations with various stakeholders to develop and disseminate climate-informed decision-making tools for land managers and agricultural leaders. These hubs serve as a network of regional centers focused on addressing the impacts of climate change on agriculture and natural resources. To provide climate-informed decision-making tools, the Climate Hubs are utilizing partnerships and collaborations in several ways: 1. **Interagency Collaborations**: The Climate Hubs partner with other federal agencies, such as the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) and the Department of Interior's Bureau of Land Management, to access climate data, research, and expertise. 2. **Universities and Research Institutions**: The Climate Hubs collaborate with universities and research institutions to advance climate science and develop decision-making tools tailored to specific regional needs. 3. **State and Local Governments**: Partnerships with state and local governments facilitate the dissemination of climate information and decision-making tools to land managers, farmers, and ranchers at the local level. 4. **Private Sector Organizations**: The Climate Hubs work with private sector organizations, such as insurance companies and agricultural cooperatives, to develop practical solutions for managing climate-related risks in agriculture. 5. **Indigenous Communities**: The Climate Hubs engage with indigenous communities to incorporate traditional knowledge and values into decision-making processes related to climate change adaptation and mitigation. By fostering these partnerships and collaborations, the USDA Climate Hubs are providing land managers and agricultural leaders with: 1. **Climate data and projections**: Access to high-quality climate data and projections helps inform decisions about crop selection, irrigation management, and pest and disease management. 2. **Decision-making tools**: The Climate Hubs develop and disseminate decision-support tools, such as risk assessments, economic models, and climate-smart agriculture frameworks, tailored to specific regional needs. 3. **Training and capacity building**: Partnerships with universities, research institutions, and other stakeholders enable the Climate Hubs to provide training and capacity-building opportunities for land managers and agricultural leaders. 4. **Extension services**: The Climate Hubs facilitate the extension of climate information and decision-making tools to rural communities through partnerships with local organizations and extension agents. By leveraging these partnerships and collaborations, the USDA Climate Hubs are helping land managers and agricultural leaders make informed decisions in the face of changing climate conditions, ultimately supporting more resilient and sustainable agriculture and natural resource management practices.

Content: Show Us When You Are   Cross-posted from FoodSafety.gov blog: Summer is finally here! I can smell those steaks and burgers on the grill already. While grilling outside with our friends and family can be fun, it can also lead to food poisoning. This summer, the USDA Food Safety and Inspection Service is reminding Americans everywhere that ¡°Grilling Like a PRO¡± is the safest and easiest way to grill. You can¡¯t see harmful bacteria on your burgers, chicken, and steak¡ªusing a food thermometer is the only way to know that your food is safe to eat. The PRO method is an easy way to protect you and your family from foodborne illness.  Kristina Beaugh, MPH, Food Safety Education Staff, Food Safety and Inspection Service, USDA  Posted in  Health and Safety  Jul 02,   1 Response
Question: What is the best way to ensure your grilled meats are safe to eat, according to the PRO method recommended by USDA Food Safety and Inspection Service?
True Answer: According to the PRO method, using a food thermometer is the best way to ensure your grilled meats (burgers, chicken, steak) are safe to eat.
Generated Answer: According to the PRO method recommended by the USDA Food Safety and Inspection Service, the best way to ensure your grilled meats are safe to eat is: **P**: **Prevent Cross-Contamination** Ensure that raw meat, poultry, or seafood is stored separately from ready-to-eat foods in a clean and covered container. Prevent juices from coming into contact with other foods. **R**: **Reach a Safe Minimum Internal Temperature (SMIT)** Use a food thermometer to ensure your grilled meats have reached the recommended internal temperature: + Beef, pork, lamb: 145¡ãF (63¡ãC) + Ground meats: 160¡ãF (71¡ãC) + Chicken and turkey: 165¡ãF (74¡ãC) **O**: **Once Done, Let it Rest** After grilling, let your meat rest for 3-4 minutes to allow juices to redistribute. This helps prevent bacterial growth. By following these simple steps, you can ensure that your grilled meats are safe to eat and enjoy!

Content: Teaching Kids Food Safety Tips for a Healthy Next Generation  The Food Safety and Inspection Service (FSIS) ensures that America¡¯s meat, poultry, and processed egg products are safe and wholesome. Educating the public on proper food handling practices is a core agency mission as well. It¡¯s even more important when one considers the impact safe food handling practices have on children. With a generation of children brought up relating the word ¡°celebrity¡± to chefs just as readily as they do to athletes, food safety education has a more receptive audience among teens and young adults than ever before. With the help of parents and guardians, the current generation of children could have fewer preventable cases of foodborne illness than ever before.  James Croxon, Food Safety and Inspection Service, Congressional and Public Affairs  Posted in  Health and Safety  Mar 20,   2 Responses
Question: What role can parents and guardians play in educating the current generation of children to have fewer preventable cases of foodborne illness?
True Answer: Parents and guardians can play a significant role in educating the current generation of children about safe food handling practices, helping them learn essential skills to prevent foodborne illnesses.
Generated Answer: Parents and guardians can play a significant role in educating the current generation of children to have fewer preventable cases of foodborne illness. Here are some ways they can contribute: 1. **Modeling healthy behavior**: Children often mimic their parents' actions, so it's crucial for parents and guardians to model safe eating habits themselves. 2. **Teaching proper hand hygiene**: Parents should teach children the importance of washing hands with soap and water before eating and after handling food. 3. **Supervising meal preparation**: Guardians can supervise children while they prepare meals or snacks, ensuring they follow basic food safety guidelines like separating raw meat from ready-to-eat foods. 4. **Educating about safe food storage**: Parents should teach children how to store food properly in the fridge or freezer and check expiration dates before consuming perishable items. 5. **Promoting proper food handling**: Guardians can educate children on how to handle food safely, such as not cross-contaminating foods or cooking meat to a safe internal temperature. 6. **Encouraging a balanced diet**: Parents should encourage their children to eat a variety of fruits and vegetables to reduce the risk of foodborne illness from undercooked or raw foods. 7. **Discussing food allergies and intolerances**: Guardians can educate children about common food allergies, such as peanuts or shellfish, and teach them how to identify potential allergens in different foods. By taking these steps, parents and guardians can empower their children with the knowledge they need to make informed choices and reduce their risk of contracting foodborne illnesses.

Content: Proud to Serve My Country  When USDA recognized the men and women who served our country at the annual USDA Veterans Day Observance, it was a special day for me. That¡¯s because the observance, held Oct. 27, , was my first as a USDA employee since returning from a Navy individual augmentee deployment to Kabul, Afghanistan in December of .   It has been more than a year since I answered the call to mobilize. Saying goodbye to your family and friends is never easy. Leaving my job at USDA was not easy, either. But I have no regrets answering that call to duty because for me-- and for my fellow USDA employees who are still serving in the reserve or guard -- we have great support from family, friends, and coworkers.     Fred Cheng, Diversity & Inclusion Program Manager and US Navy Reserve Member  Posted in  USDA Results  Initiatives  Nov 15,   Respond to this story

Content: Forest Service Research & Development in  Conservation  Forestry  Research and Science  Mar 03,  Kellie Carim, eDNA coordinator for the Genomics Center, collects and processes samples. (Photos by Michael Schwartz (left) and Katie Zarn, U.S. Forest Service) This post is part of the Science Tuesday feature series on the USDA blog. Check back each week as we showcase stories and news from USDA¡¯s rich science and research profile. The U.S. Forest Service has a long history as a leader in conservation genetics, and this recently took an exciting step forward with the launch of the National Genomics Center for Wildlife and Fish Conservation. The Forest Service¡¯s wildlife genetics lab, which has been central to the Rocky Mountain Research Station¡¯s conservation genetics program since , has been reorganized and renamed to better reflect the scope of its work nationwide. The Center is a leading edge facility for advanced genomics research, nationally recognized, and works extensively with states, tribes, universities and private groups to address the management issues of over 60 fish and wildlife species.  collected by the Center will support the new Forest Service Forest Planning Rule with timely and cost-effective information on wildlife and fish species. Information developed by the Center will be made available through the network of USDA Climate Hubs to assist private forestland managers, farmers and ranchers in reaching their conservation goals. With state-of-the-art technology and the development of new tools and techniques, the main objective of the Center is to provide cost-effective and reliable genomic for improved species monitoring. By having more robust information, state and federal managers are better able to evaluate the genetic health and population viability of fish and wildlife species across the landscape. The discovery of a new fish species and the detection of invasive species are among the Center¡¯s many contributions to the advancement of science and management. Imagine an expansive landscape, filled with different and remote terrain, and being asked to determine if the area has been impacted by a new invasive species. This is a daunting challenge that land managers face on a regular basis. One of the Center¡¯s specialties, analyzing samples of environmental DNA, or eDNA, shows great promise in addressing this challenge. This type of DNA has been separated from organisms into the surrounding environment and can be found in soil, water and air. Forest Service scientists are developing ways to determine what species are present by simply sampling a cup of water from locations across the landscape. ¡°eDNA is a highly sensitive method for detecting organisms in low abundance and is generally faster and extremely cost effective compared to traditional methods used to detect exotic or endangered species,¡± said Dr. Michael Schwartz, director of the center. The use of eDNA is an innovative approach to inventorying and monitoring fish and wildlife species. eDNA is particularly effective for detecting rare species that can be difficult to sample using traditional methods. For example, researchers at the Rocky Mountain Research Station have been working with partners and collaborators on the threatened bull trout (Salvelinus confluentus) since . Bull trout is a culturally significant species to several Tribes in the Northwest and Columbia River Basin. It is also a prized game fish, and land management and recreational angling are significantly influenced by whether or not this species is present in a given watershed. This species is particularly sensitive to changes in habitat and is also threatened by the introduction of the nonnative brook trout (S. fontinalis). Forest Service scientists have developed sampling methods to make eDNA surveys a reliable and accessible option for managers to detect the presence of bull trout and their invasive competitor, brook trout. Forest Service scientists continue to develop eDNA techniques for detecting priority fish and wildlife.  eDNA is just one method of non-invasive genetic sampling, which uses forensic-style DNA samples to monitor rare and sensitive species, employed by the Center. A Bull trout swims in a stream. (Photo courtesy of U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service)  Category/Topic:  Conservation  Forestry  Research and Science  Tags:  climate hub  Conservation  DNA  eDNA  Forestry  FS  genetics  Rocky Mountain Research Station
Question: What innovative method is being used by the National Genomics Center for Wildlife and Fish Conservation to detect rare species, such as bull trout, in a cost-effective and non-invasive way?
True Answer: The National Genomics Center for Wildlife and Fish Conservation is using Environmental DNA (eDNA) sampling, which involves analyzing DNA found in soil, water, or air, to detect rare species like bull trout in a cost-effective and non-invasive manner.
Generated Answer: Unfortunately, I couldn't find any specific information on the National Genomics Center for Wildlife and Fish Conservation or its use of an innovative method to detect rare species. It's possible that this is not a real organization. However, I can provide some general information on methods used to detect rare species. The use of genetic analysis, such as DNA sampling from environmental samples (e.g., water or tissue), has become increasingly popular for detecting rare and elusive species in cost-effective and non-invasive ways. This approach involves collecting environmental samples and then analyzing the genetic material present within them using advanced sequencing technologies like next-generation sequencing (NGS). Another technique used to detect rare species is eDNA (environmental DNA) analysis. eDNA analysis involves collecting water or sediment samples from a specific location and then analyzing the DNA fragments present in those samples to identify the species that may be present. Additionally, camera traps and drone-based monitoring systems are also being employed for detecting rare species without causing them harm. However, I couldn't find any specific information on an organization called the National Genomics Center for Wildlife and Fish Conservation. If you have more context or details about this organization, I'd be happy to try and help further!

Content: A Small Business Dream Built on a Farmers Market  My mom raised five kids, taught high school chemistry for 15 years and then retired back to the family farm in . Her new life on the farm depended on the Salisbury, MD farmers market where she sold daylilies.  The farmers market, just one of 8,000 or more markets listed in USDA¡¯s National Farmers Market Directory, gave her the opportunity she needed to start her own business. Each Saturday she loaded up her station wagon with plants and drove into town, displaying the lilies by color.  When she wanted to expand her plant offerings, my brother built her a small greenhouse.  She became known as the farmers market¡¯s Flower Lady.  Peter Wood, Public Affairs Specialist, AMS Public Affairs  Posted in  Food and Nutrition  Farming  Oct 26,   10 Responses
Question: What opportunities did the Salisbury, MD farmers market provide for my mom to start her own business selling daylilies?
True Answer: The Salisbury, MD farmers market provided my mom with the opportunity to sell daylilies and eventually start her own business.
Generated Answer: The Salisbury, MD farmers market provided several opportunities for your mom to start her own business selling daylilies: 1. **Exposure and visibility**: The market gave your mom a platform to showcase her products (daylilies) in front of potential customers who were already interested in local produce and handmade items. 2. **Access to a built-in customer base**: As a regular market participant, your mom could interact with repeat customers who might be more likely to become loyal buyers of her daylily business. 3. **Opportunity to test products and pricing**: By selling at the market, your mom could gauge demand for her daylilies, get feedback from customers, and refine her product offerings and pricing strategy based on customer responses. 4. **Networking opportunities**: The Salisbury farmers market likely attracted other local vendors, artisans, and entrepreneurs who might be interested in collaborating or learning from each other's experiences. 5. **Low-risk entry point for new business ventures**: Participating in a managed market like the Salisbury farmers market can be less intimidating than launching a standalone business, as it provides a supportive environment with established rules and regulations. These opportunities likely helped your mom take the first steps towards building her daylily business, which might have eventually grown into a successful enterprise.

Content: Where the People and Prairie Restore Each Other  Meandering along a rustic trail surrounded by towering prairie grasses and blooming flowers, you feel a sense of simplicity as you come to a quiet overlook that slopes onto a bench where you can observe the activity of birds and small mammals surrounding a still pond. This beautiful prairie landscape leaves the viewer with an appreciation for nature¡¯s wide open spaces. And, amazingly, you¡¯re in the middle of one of America¡¯s most populated regions because this could only be the Midewin (mi-Day-win) National Tallgrass Prairie, the largest piece of contiguous open space in the Chicago metropolitan area, located just an hour¡¯s drive from the heart of the Windy City.  Leah Anderson, U.S. Forest Service  Posted in  Forestry  May 05,   Respond to this story
Question: What role does the Tallgrass Prairie play in balancing human population density with natural beauty and wildlife preservation?
True Answer: The Tallgrass Prairie plays a key role in balancing human population density with natural beauty and wildlife preservation by providing a large contiguous open space within a highly populated metropolitan area, allowing for the coexistence of urban development and protected natural habitats.
Generated Answer: The Tallgrass Prairie, a unique ecosystem found in North America, plays a significant role in balancing human population density with natural beauty and wildlife preservation. Here's how: **Preservation of Natural Beauty**: The Tallgrass Prairie is known for its stunning vistas, diverse wildflowers, and majestic grasses that sway gently in the breeze. As an intact prairie ecosystem, it offers visitors a chance to experience the essence of nature in its purest form. This natural beauty provides a tranquil escape from the hustle and bustle of urban life, promoting recreation, relaxation, and appreciation for the environment. **Wildlife Preservation**: The Tallgrass Prairie is home to over 700 species of plants and animals, many of which are rare or endangered. By preserving this ecosystem, it serves as a vital habitat for numerous species, including prairie chickens, monarch butterflies, and various species of grassland birds. This preservation ensures the long-term survival of these species, contributing to biodiversity conservation. **Balancing Human Population Density**: The Tallgrass Prairie offers opportunities for responsible human development that balance natural beauty and wildlife preservation with community needs. For instance: 1. **Conservation-friendly land use**: Zoning regulations and careful planning ensure that new developments are situated in areas that minimize impact on the prairie ecosystem. 2. **Education and outreach**: Educational programs, guided tours, and outreach initiatives raise awareness about the importance of conservation, promoting responsible human interaction with nature. 3. **Recreational activities**: Activities like hiking, birdwatching, and horseback riding encourage people to experience the natural beauty of the Tallgrass Prairie while minimizing their impact on the ecosystem. **Benefits for Human Communities**: The Tallgrass Prairie also offers numerous benefits to local communities: 1. **Economic benefits**: Tourism, outdoor recreation, and eco-friendly industries contribute to the regional economy. 2. **Quality of life**: Access to green spaces, parks, and natural areas improves mental health, reduces stress, and enhances overall quality of life for residents. In summary, the Tallgrass Prairie plays a vital role in balancing human population density with natural beauty and wildlife preservation by promoting: 1. Conservation-friendly land use 2. Education and outreach initiatives 3. Recreational activities that minimize impact on the ecosystem 4. Economic benefits through eco-tourism and sustainable industries 5. Quality of life improvements for local communities. By preserving this unique ecosystem, we can ensure a harmonious coexistence between human populations and nature, maintaining the delicate balance essential for the well-being of both humans and wildlife.

Content: Thanksgiving Leftovers for Safe Keeping, Weekend Grazing  Thanksgiving Day is for family and friends. But Thanksgiving weekend is all about you and those amazing leftovers! Before you dig in, keep these tips handy so that leftovers can stay safely stored in the fridge or freezer.  Luis Delgadillo, Senior Public Affairs Specialist  Posted in  Health and Safety  Nov 23,   1 Response
Question: What are some essential guidelines for storing Thanksgiving leftovers to ensure they remain safe to eat?
True Answer: Store leftovers safely in the fridge or freezer with these tips.
Generated Answer: Here are some essential guidelines for storing Thanksgiving leftovers to ensure they remain safe to eat: 1. **Cool leftovers quickly**: Within 2 hours of cooking, make sure all leftovers have cooled down to room temperature. This is crucial in preventing bacterial growth. 2. **Refrigerate promptly**: Refrigerate cooked leftovers within 2 hours of cooling. Use shallow containers to speed up the cooling process and prevent moisture buildup. 3. **Label and date containers**: Clearly label each container with the contents and date stored. This will help you keep track of how long they've been in storage. 4. **Store safely at refrigerator temperature (40¡ãF/4¡ãC)**: Ensure your refrigerator is set to 40¡ãF (4¡ãC) or below to prevent bacterial growth. 5. **Consume within 3-4 days**: Use leftovers within 3-4 days of refrigeration. If you don't plan to eat them within this timeframe, consider freezing. 6. **Freeze safely**: When freezing leftovers, use airtight containers or freezer bags, and label them with the contents and date stored. Frozen leftovers can be stored for up to 3 months. 7. **Reheat to proper temperature**: Reheat leftovers to an internal temperature of 165¡ãF (74¡ãC) before consuming. 8. **Discard if in doubt**: If you're unsure about the safety or quality of a leftover, it's best to discard it. Additional tips: * Avoid cross-contamination by storing raw and cooked foods separately. * Use shallow containers to prevent moisture buildup and promote even cooling. * Keep leftovers away from strong-smelling foods, as they can absorb odors easily. * Be mindful of the " Danger Zone" (40¡ãF/4¡ãC to 140¡ãF/60¡ãC) where bacteria can grow rapidly. By following these guidelines, you'll be able to enjoy your Thanksgiving leftovers while ensuring they remain safe and enjoyable to eat.

Content: Interactive Online Resource to Learn about Climate Change Adaptation  The Climate Change Resource Center (CCRC) has recently released a new education resource on climate change adaptation responses to help the USDA Forest Service, USDA Climate Hubs, other agencies, and the general public learn more about responding to a changing climate.  The CCRC is an online, nationally-relevant resource that connects land managers and decision-makers with credible, relevant, and useable science to address climate change in natural resource planning and application. Natural resource managers are already observing changes in their forests and rangelands and experiencing challenges managing these lands in a changing climate.  In order to continue to maintain healthy forests and rangelands into the future, land managers need to understand how to address these challenges and respond to climate change effects.  This requires that managers assess the vulnerabilities and risks associated with climate change and choose the best course of action for the landscapes they manage.  Kailey Marcinkowski, Northern Research Station, U.S. Forest Service  Posted in  Initiatives  Forestry  Dec 21,   Respond to this story
Question: What steps can land managers take to assess vulnerabilities and address challenges associated with climate change in order to maintain healthy forests and rangelands into the future?
True Answer: Land managers should assess vulnerabilities and risks associated with climate change by choosing the best course of action for their managed landscapes, taking proactive steps to address these challenges.
Generated Answer: Land managers can take several steps to assess vulnerabilities and address challenges associated with climate change in order to maintain healthy forests and rangelands: 1. **Conduct Climate Change Vulnerability Assessments**: Conduct assessments to identify areas of high vulnerability, such as regions with sensitive ecosystems, critical habitat for endangered species, or areas with significant cultural or spiritual significance. 2. **Monitor Climate-Related Indicators**: Monitor climate-related indicators, such as temperature, precipitation, and drought patterns, to understand the local impacts of climate change. 3. **Assess Forest/Rangeland Conditions**: Conduct field assessments to evaluate forest and rangeland conditions, including vegetation structure, species composition, soil health, and hydrologic characteristics. 4. **Engage Stakeholders**: Engage stakeholders, including indigenous communities, landowners, users, and other relevant parties, to gather input on the social, cultural, and economic aspects of climate change impacts. 5. **Develop Climate-Smart Management Plans**: Develop management plans that take into account projected climate scenarios, prioritize conservation efforts, and identify potential opportunities for adaptation and mitigation. 6. **Prioritize Adaptive Management Practices**: Implement adaptive management practices, such as thinning, prescribed burning, or assisted migration, to help forests and rangelands adapt to changing climate conditions. 7. **Invest in Climate Change Research and Development**: Support research and development of new technologies, tools, and strategies that can help land managers address the challenges associated with climate change. 8. **Implement Ecosystem-Based Management (EBM)**: Implement EBM principles to ensure that forest and rangeland management decisions consider ecosystem-wide relationships between species, habitats, and processes. 9. **Develop Resilience-Enhancing Strategies**: Develop strategies to enhance resilience in forests and rangelands, such as promoting diversity, reducing disturbance, or creating connectivity between ecosystems. 10. **Communicate with the Public and Stakeholders**: Communicate climate-related findings and management plans with the public, stakeholders, and decision-makers to build trust, promote understanding, and secure support for climate-resilient land management practices. By taking these steps, land managers can better assess vulnerabilities, address challenges associated with climate change, and maintain healthy forests and rangelands into the future.

Content: North Dakota USDA Public Information Specialist, and Josh Kramer, USDA Community Program Specialist in  Rural  Dec 02,   USDA Rural Development State Director Jasper Schneider, and staff, recently toured seven rural communities in southwestern North Dakota as part of USDA¡¯s ongoing commitment to rural communities.  Schneider participated in conversations with community leaders to identify ways Rural Development programs can most effectively work to improve the quality of life and increase economic opportunity in the region. Some stops on the tour included a multi-family housing complex, that acquired  new siding, doors, windows and some updating inside. Last year USDA provided a loan and a grant thanks to the Multi-family Housing Preservation Revitalization Restructuring Program (MPR). State Director Schneider also visited Hettinger Theater, which  received financing for new state-of-the-art high definition/3D equipment from USDA¡¯s Rural Business Enterprise Grant (RBEG) as a result of the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act.  Ed Gold, Economic Developer for Adams County, was excited to share with Schneider his appreciation for the agency¡¯s support for small businesses. On the last day of the tour, State Director Schneider recognized three entities for their strong leadership to increase economic development in rural communities with a Rural Business Opportunity Grant (RBOG) award.  They include Prairie West Development Foundation which received a grant to do a feasibility study on a proposed waste paper recycling and manufacturing center; and Roosevelt-Custer Regional Council which received a grant to address the impact that energy development is having on communities located in the Southwest Rural Economic Area Partnership (REAP) Zone. Also acknowledged was the city of New England, which received a grant to study a proposed glass recycling business to be located in the city. Seven cities and seven counties later, State Director Schneider and Rural Development staff were able to have meaningful discussions with a total of nearly 150 community leaders. Schneider¡¯s visit helped highlight the positive growth made possible by USDA¡¯s investments in rural communities. For more information about USDA Rural Development programs and how they can assist your community, click here. Rural Development State Director Jasper Schneider (Center) meets with community leaders during a recent outreach meeting in Regent. Rural Development State Director Jasper Schneider (Right) accompanied by Ed Gold, Economic Developer for Adams County (Left) on a tour of businesses funded by USDA Rural Development, during a stop in Hettinger. Content: Recreation, Heritage and Volunteer Resources, U.S. Forest Service in  Forestry  Sep 23,  A Forest Service employee, along with Woodsy Owl, pose with kids from the Girl Scott¡¯s Daisy program during National Public Lands Day (Photo Credit: US Forest Service. Organizing the largest single-day volunteer effort in support of public lands in the country, National Public Lands Day, is no easy feat for the U.S. Forest Service. That¡¯s 40 days of volunteer projects, BioBlitzes, fishing derbies, and educational events, all of which are registered with the National Environmental Education Foundation, the organization that started National Public Lands Day 23 years ago. Despite its origins as a volunteer event, National Public Lands Day is more than just service. This year¡¯s tagline, Learn, Play, and Volunteer, emphasizes connecting people with the natural world through education and recreation as well as volunteerism, and partnerships forming around this year¡¯s events embody NPLD¡¯s expanding scope. The focus is Every Kid in a Park: a multi-agency effort to connect fourth-graders with their public lands through educational events and year-long free passes to national forests and parks. For Carmen Young, the Forest Service Public Lands Day lead, it¡¯s a labor of love. "It was so great seeing all the kids playing outside, learning about how water comes from forests and gets to our faucets, and contributing to water monitoring efforts in the D.C. area,¡± said Young. This year¡¯s events are already in the works: from trail clearing to citizen science, there¡¯s something for everyone. National Public Lands Day runs from Sept. 1-Oct. 10 on Forest Service sites all over America.  Category/Topic:  Forestry  Tags:  Forest Service  Forestry  National Public Lands Day  Woodsy Owl

Content: 10 in Conservation and Forestry You Should Know  At the beginning of this year, we launched a year-long reflection on USDA-wide results achieved over the course of this Administration. This week begins a month-long focus on seven years of USDA accomplishments to preserve our natural resources for tomorrow¡¯s generations ¨C accomplishments that have only been made possible with the hard work of our staff at USDA and the support of our steadfast partners. I¡¯m proud of the work that we¡¯ve done to build lasting partnerships to care for our nation¡¯s unparalleled public lands and support producers as they conserve our nation¡¯s land, water and soil. Please take some time to read a full story of our results on my Medium page at: www.medium.com/usda-results.  Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack  Posted in  Conservation  Forestry  USDA Results  Feb 04,   4 Responses
Question: What role have steadfast partners played in supporting USDA's conservation and forestry efforts, particularly in preserving the nation's public lands?
True Answer: Steadfast partners have played a significant role in supporting USDA's conservation and forestry efforts, particularly in preserving the nation's public lands. Their support has been essential to building lasting partnerships that care for these resources.
Generated Answer: Steadfast partners have played a significant role in supporting the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) Conservation and Forestry efforts, specifically in preserving the nation's public lands. These partners include: 1. **National Forest Foundation** (NFF): As the official nonprofit partner of the US Forest Service, NFF has collaborated with USDA to support conservation, recreation, and environmental education on national forests. 2. **The Nature Conservancy**: This international environmental organization has worked with USDA to protect and restore natural habitats on public lands, including forests, grasslands, and wetlands. 3. **National Association of State Foresters** (NASF): NASF has partnered with USDA's Forest Service to support state forestry agencies in promoting healthy forests, reducing wildfire risk, and fostering ecosystem services. 4. **The Wildlife Habitat Incentives Program** (WHIP) partners: These organizations have collaborated with USDA's Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS) to develop and implement conservation plans for private lands, while also protecting public lands. These steadfast partners have contributed significantly to the preservation of America's natural resources by: * Supporting conservation efforts on public lands through partnerships and grants * Providing expertise in environmental education and outreach programs * Facilitating collaborative management practices with federal agencies * Advocating for policy changes that benefit forestry and conservation efforts Through their collective efforts, these steadfast partners have helped USDA's Conservation and Forestry programs achieve a range of successes, including: * Protecting watersheds and maintaining water quality * Preserving biodiversity and ecosystem services * Reducing the risk of wildfires and promoting healthy forests * Enhancing public access to natural resources for recreation and education By working together with steadfast partners like these organizations, USDA has been able to make significant progress in preserving America's precious public lands for future generations.

Content: Hoosier National Forest in  May 13,  Bedford, Ind., May 5, -- A group of Hoosier National Forest employees plant chestnut trees in a timber sale area of the Hoosier to return the American chestnut to its native range (Photo Credit: US Forest Service). Once a prominent phenomenon in southern Indiana, Bedford just experienced the first re-planting of American chestnut trees on the Hoosier National Forest in partnership with Purdue University and the U.S. Forest Service¡¯s Northern Research Station. ¡°Historically, the American chestnut was once one of the most important trees in the eastern United States, occupying about 25 percent of the hardwood canopy in eastern forests,¡± said David Cleaves, climate change advisor for the Forest Service. The trees grew to be 80 feet tall or more, and were known as ¡®the redwood of the East.¡¯  By the s, the tree was nearly wiped out by an Asian fungus known as chestnut blight.  The restoration of American chestnut to eastern forests depends on the development of blight-resistant seedlings. The Forest Service, American Chestnut Foundation, and the University of Tennessee have been conducting research and tests to produce a blight-resistant American chestnut, with aspirations of restoring the species in its grandeur. Bedford, Ind., May 5, -- Forest Botanist Kirk Larson (foreground) plants an American chestnut tree on the Hoosier National Forest to return the American chestnut to its native range (Photo Credit: US Forest Service).  A traditional back-cross breeding method is being used to create blight-resistant American chestnut seedlings, which are 94 percent American chestnut and 6 percent Chinese chestnut --- and are blight resistant. The restoration effort began when the American Chestnut Restoration Project partners planted seedlings in three national forests in Virginia, Tennessee and North Carolina in early . Scientists say the seedlings are surpassing expectations of survival and they are cautiously optimistic. A full decade will need to pass before massive replanting begins.  But the trees will be given every opportunity to do well. They were planted in a fenced enclosure to keep out deer and minimize damage from wildlife, and herbicides will be applied as needed to control undesirable competition. The fenced enclosure was built with help from fire crews from the Ottawa and White Mountain National Forests as well as Hoosier employees.  Ron Doyle planted the first blight-resistant American chestnut on the Hoosier National Forest, unofficially in honor of his father -- a long-time member of the American Chestnut Foundation. His father, now in a nursing home, was very pleased to hear the trees were returning to Indiana. Another Indiana site will be planted in .  Tags:  Bedford  Climate Change  David Cleaves  Forestry  FS  Indiana  Northern Research Station
Question: "What are the key factors involved in the massive replanting effort of American chestnut trees on Hoosier National Forest, and what makes these seedlings resistant to the blight that nearly wiped out the species?"
True Answer: 1. **Development of blight-resistant seedlings**: A traditional back-cross breeding method was used to create seedlings that are 94% American chestnut and 6% Chinese chestnut, making them resistant to the Asian fungus known as chestnut blight. 2. **Fenced enclosure protection**: The seedlings were planted in a fenced enclosure to protect them from deer and other wildlife that could damage or harm them. 3. **Herbicides for weed control**: Herbicides will be applied as needed to control undesirable competition and prevent the spread of invasive species. These measures, combined with a decade-long wait period before massive replanting begins, are designed to give the seedlings every opportunity to thrive and eventually restore the American chestnut tree to its former prominence in eastern forests.
Generated Answer: The massive replanting effort of American chestnut trees on Hoosier National Forest is part of a broader conservation initiative led by the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Forest Service, in collaboration with the Indiana Department of Natural Resources and other organizations. The key factors involved in this effort include: 1. **Genetic resistance**: Scientists have identified specific genetic traits within American chestnut populations that confer natural resistance to the chestnut blight (Cryphonectria parasitica), a fungal disease caused by a pathogen introduced from Asia. These resistant genotypes are being used as seed sources for replanting. 2. **Backcross breeding**: To enhance the genetic resistance of American chestnuts, researchers have developed a backcross breeding program that involves crossing blight-resistant Chinese chestnut trees with American chestnuts. This process has helped to introduce and amplify desirable traits into the American population, making them more resilient to the disease. 3. **Cryopreservation and seed orchards**: To ensure a reliable supply of resistant seeds for replanting, scientists have developed cryopreservation techniques to bank seeds from blight-resistant trees. These seeds are then used in controlled seed orchards to produce high-quality planting stock. 4. **Sapling cultivation and nursery management**: Specialized nurseries cultivate saplings from these resistant seed sources, using specific growing conditions and treatments to minimize disease pressure. This helps ensure that the young trees have a strong foundation for growth and resistance. The key features of these resistant American chestnut seedlings include: 1. **Resistance genes**: The blight-resistant genotypes used in replanting efforts carry genetic traits that inhibit the fungal pathogen's ability to infect the tree. 2. **Enhanced vigor**: These seedlings exhibit improved growth rates, leaf quality, and overall health compared to their unimproved counterparts. 3. **Improved root development**: Resistant American chestnut seedlings tend to have stronger, more extensive root systems, which helps them better compete with invasive species and withstand environmental stressors. The replanting effort on Hoosier National Forest is critical for restoring the ecological role of American chestnuts in these ecosystems. By reintroducing blight-resistant trees, conservationists hope to: 1. **Recreate complex forest structures**: American chestnut's towering canopies once played a vital role in structuring the Hoosier National Forest landscape. Restoring these dominant trees will help recreate a more diverse and resilient ecosystem. 2. **Support biodiversity**: The return of American chestnuts is expected to boost local biodiversity, as their presence supports a range of associated species, from wildlife to pollinators. 3. **Promote ecological resilience**: By establishing blight-resistant American chestnut populations, the long-term goal is to enhance the forest's ability to withstand and adapt to changing environmental conditions. This concerted effort represents a significant step toward restoring America's iconic chestnut trees and promoting a more resilient, diverse, and dynamic ecosystem on Hoosier National Forest.

Content: Manager, USDA Meat and Poultry Hotline in  Health and Safety  May 25,  Cook pork, roasts, and chops to 145 oF as measured with a food thermometer, then allow the meat to rest for three minutes before carving or consuming. Cross posted from the FoodSafety.gov blog:  On May 24, USDA made some important changes in their recommended cooking temperatures for meats. Here¡¯s what you need to know: Cooking Whole Cuts of Pork: USDA has lowered the recommended safe cooking temperature for whole cuts of pork from 160 oF to 145 oF with the addition of a three-minute rest time. Cook pork, roasts, and chops to 145 oF as measured with a food thermometer before removing meat from the heat source, with a three-minute rest time before carving or consuming. This will result in a product that is both safe and at its best quality¡ªjuicy and tender. Cooking Whole Cuts of Other Meats: For beef, veal, and lamb cuts, the safe temperature remains unchanged at 145 oF, but the department has added a three-minute rest time as part of its cooking recommendations. What Cooking Temperatures Didn¡¯t Change? Ground Meats: This change does not apply to ground meats, including beef, veal, lamb, and pork, which should be cooked to 160 oF and do not require a rest time. Poultry: The safe cooking temperature for all poultry products, including ground chicken and turkey, stays the same at 165 oF. What Is Rest Time?  ¡°Rest time¡± is the amount of time the product remains at the final temperature, after it has been removed from a grill, oven or other heat source. During the three minutes after meat is removed the heat source, its temperature remains constant or continues to rise, which destroys harmful bacteria. Why Did the Recommendations Change? It¡¯s just as safe to cook cuts of pork to 145 o F with a three-minute rest time as it is to cook them to 160 oF, the previously recommended temperature, with no rest time. The new cooking recommendations reflect the same standards that the agency uses for cooked meat products produced in federally inspected meat establishments, which rely on the rest time of three minutes to achieve a safe product. Having a single time and temperature combination for all meat will help consumers remember the temperature at which they can be sure the meat is safe to eat. How Do You Use a Food Thermometer? Place the food thermometer in the thickest part of the food. It should not touch bone, fat, or gristle. Start checking the temperature toward the end of cooking, but before you expect it to be done. Be sure to clean your food thermometer with hot soapy water before and after each use. To see where to place a food thermometer in different cuts of meat, see Thermometer Placement and Temperatures. For more information on cooking temperatures for all types of food, see the Safe Minimum Cooking Temperatures chart. If you have questions about cooking meat, feel free to contact us at the Hotline or online at Ask USDA.  Category/Topic:  Health and Safety  Tags:  Ask Karen  Food Safety  food thermometer  FoodSafety.gov
Question: "What is the recommended safe cooking temperature for whole cuts of pork, according to the USDA, and how does it differ from the previously recommended temperature?"
True Answer: According to the USDA, the recommended safe cooking temperature for whole cuts of pork is 145 oF with a three-minute rest time, which differs from the previously recommended temperature of 160 oF.
Generated Answer: According to the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA), the recommended safe cooking temperature for whole cuts of pork has changed over time. As of 2011, the USDA revised its guidelines to reflect a change in the understanding of food safety. The previous recommended safe internal temperature for pork was 160¡ãF (71¡ãC). However, this recommendation was based on outdated research that suggested trichinosis, a parasitic infection caused by Trichinella spiralis, could be found in pork if it was not heated to an extremely high temperature. In 2011, the USDA changed its guidelines, stating that cooking whole cuts of pork to an internal temperature of 145¡ãF (63¡ãC) with a 3-minute rest time is sufficient to ensure food safety. This revised recommendation is based on research that shows trichinosis can be eliminated at lower temperatures than previously thought. It's essential to note that ground pork, however, should still be cooked to an internal temperature of 160¡ãF (71¡ãC).

Content: Pet Waste Disposal Systems Help Protect Water Quality  Dog waste that isn¡¯t cleaned up isn¡¯t just a hazard for the bottom of your shoes¡ªit is also a cause of pollution in creeks, rivers and lakes across the country. Dog waste contains nitrogen and phosphorus, which can deplete oxygen that fish and other water-based life need to survive, as well as encourage the growth of harmful algae. It is also considered a significant source of pathogens like fecal coliform, a disease-causing bacteria.  Amy Overstreet Maxwell and Sabrenna Bryant, NRCS South Carolina  Posted in  Conservation  Mar 08,   1 Response
Question: What are the primary sources of pollution in waterways when pet waste is not disposed of properly?
True Answer: The primary sources of pollution in waterways due to improperly disposed pet waste are nitrogen and phosphorus, which deplete oxygen for fish and other aquatic life, and pathogens like fecal coliform bacteria.
Generated Answer: When pet waste is not disposed of properly, it can lead to several issues that contribute to waterway pollution. The primary sources of pollution in this scenario include: 1. **Bacteria and Pathogens**: Pet waste contains bacteria like E. coli, Salmonella, and Campylobacter, which can contaminate nearby waterways. These pathogens can pose a health risk to humans, especially those who engage in activities like swimming or fishing in polluted waters. 2. **Nutrient Pollution (Nitrogen and Phosphorus)**: Pet waste is high in nitrogen and phosphorus, which are essential nutrients for plant growth but can be detrimental in excess. When pet waste enters waterways, it releases these nutrients into the environment, leading to algal blooms. These excessive algae growths deplete oxygen levels as they decay, harming aquatic life. 3. **Sedimentation and Turbidity**: Improper disposal of pet waste can lead to increased sediment loads in waterways. As the organic matter from pet waste breaks down, it creates suspended solids that contribute to turbidity. This reduces sunlight penetration into waters, impairing photosynthesis in aquatic plants. 4. **Excess Nutrient Loads for Aquatic Life**: Excessive nutrient inputs due to pet waste pollution can disrupt the delicate balance of the ecosystem. This can lead to an overgrowth of certain plant species, such as algae, while other beneficial aquatic life may struggle to survive due to altered water chemistry. It's essential to properly dispose of pet waste by burying it or using designated pet waste disposal bags. These measures prevent pet waste from entering storm drains and eventually waterways, mitigating the pollution sources mentioned above.

Content: Under Secretary, USDA Rural Development in  Rural  May 21,   I had the distinct pleasure of visiting the birthplace of former Agriculture Secretary Henry A. Wallace during a recent trip to Iowa.  In fact, my tour of the farm near Orient in south central Iowa happened to be May 15, the day the USDA celebrated its 150th anniversary. Wallace was Secretary of the Agriculture from March 4, until September 4, .  He served as Vice President of the United States from to under President Franklin D. Roosevelt and was also Secretary of Commerce from to . Wallace is perhaps the 20th Century¡¯s most well-known Ag Secretary and his accomplishments are monumental. The Wallace Centers of Iowa. Henry A. Wallace was born in Iowa and went on to serve as Vice President and as cabinet secretary of two departments, including USDA. He helped guide the creation of the Farm Security Administration, the Federal Crop Insurance Corporation and the Rural Electrification Administration (REA). USDA Rural Development, the mission area that I lead, traces its roots back to the REA. Food stamps (now the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program or SNAP) and the school lunch programs were also started during Wallace¡¯s time as Ag Secretary. Wallace was also dedicated to research and science. The USDA¡¯s research center in Beltsville, Maryland, became the largest and most varied scientific research station in the world during his time as Secretary. My visit to Wallace¡¯s birthplace also served another purpose as the Wallace Centers of Iowa recently received a $50,ep at a Time. This program is helping farmers in southwest Iowa add value to the fruit and vegetable they harvest by providing guidance and training on such things as food safety protocols, recipe development and testing and product placement. More and more people want to know where their food is coming from and are requesting locally grown foods. They also recognize the importance of supporting local producers and local economies. Agriculture Under Secretary for Rural Development speaks about the Department's 150th anniversary during an event at the Wallace Country Life Center I want to thank Diane Weiland and all her wonderful staff for such a great time at the Henry A. Wallace Country Life Center. It was a tremendous way to celebrate the 150th anniversary. USDA still fulfills President Lincoln¡¯s vision through our work on food, agriculture, economic development, science, natural resource conservation and a host of issues, touching the lives of every American, every day. Visit www.usda.gov/usda150 to learn more about USDA¡¯s history and plans for the future. Content: Public Affairs Specialist, Food Safety and Inspection Service in  Health and Safety  Dec 01,  BAC!?, the Discovery Zone¡¯s ¡°green bacteria¡± mascot greets Metropolitan Cooking and Entertaining Show attendees as they line up to tour the interactive and educational Food Safety Discovery Zone.  Last month, thousands of foodies packed into the Washington Convention Center for the Metropolitan Cooking and Entertaining Show to gain culinary wisdom from like Paula Deen, Guy Fieri, Giada De Laurentiis, and¡­ the USDA Food Safety Discovery Zone. Among the live demonstrations and more than 300 vendors, there consistently was a line of people waiting for a tour of the Food Safety Discovery Zone. Chefs and guests alike remarked about the 40-foot long yellow truck¡¯s uniqueness, and everyone who toured the interactive exhibit learned something new. A favorite game among visitors was trying to guess which of two identical-looking burgers had been cooked to 160 ¡ãF and was safe to eat. Using a food thermometer to check their answer, many were shocked to see that they had guessed wrong! As they exited the Discovery Zone, people grabbed free copies of the Kitchen Companion handbook, keychains with food safety reminders, and food thermometers. One couple returned to the Discovery Zone late in the afternoon to report their shock that a vendor touched raw meat and then served them a cooked sample without washing his hands. ¡°Really? Well, it¡¯s good that you noticed!  It¡¯s scary, right? It¡¯s so easy to get sick if people don¡¯t follow our recommendations,¡± Discovery Zone staffer Eileen Dykes told them, smiling. ¡°You now know what you can do to protect yourselves and your loved ones!¡± BAC!?, the Discovery Zone¡¯s ¡°green bacteria¡± costumed mascot posed for pictures with younger visitors. Appealing to foodies of all ages, the Discovery Zone staff made a big impression on the Metropolitan Cooking and Entertaining Show¡¯s attendees and showed them how they can protect themselves and their families from foodborne illness. Check the Food Safety Discovery Zone calendar to find out if the exhibit is coming to your area. In the meantime, the USDA Meat and Poultry Hotline can answer your food safety questions weekdays from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. EST. The virtual food safety expert, Ask Karen, is available 24/7 at www.AskKaren.gov or m.AskKaren.gov on your Android or iOS mobile device.
