Content: Research Microbiologist, Agricultural Research Service, National Animal Disease Center in  Animals  Health and Safety  Research and Science  Nov 20,  ARS remains committed to conducting research to our overall understanding of antimicrobial resistance in swine pathogens. This week is World Antibiotic Awareness Week and USDA¡¯s Agricultural Research Service (ARS) remains committed to using a ¡°One Health¡± approach in conducting research that will identify solutions to help prolong the usefulness of a very precious resource¡ªantibiotics. For example, ARS research includes understanding how common production practices might impact antimicrobial resistance and understanding whether certain animal pathogens may be a public health concern. Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) is one bacteria type that is a public health concern because of its resistance to some antibiotics which can make it difficult to treat. MRSA has been found in livestock ¨C mainly in swine. One particular MRSA strain, called ST5, has raised additional public health concerns because it is a major cause of human infections globally. To address these public health concerns, ARS conducted research to determine whether production practices like using in-feed zinc as an antidiarrheal agent contribute to the emergence and spread of MRSA in U.S. swine populations, and if ST5 bacterial isolates from swine and from humans are genetically related. ARS demonstrated that applying zinc in feed does not play a role in the prevalence of livestock-associated MRSA ST5 in the U.S. swine population. More importantly, ARS found that ST5 isolates from agricultural sources are genetically distinct and separate from clinical MRSA ST5 isolates obtained from human clinical settings. Specifically, isolates from agricultural sources were found to be extremely similar to each other within farms and lacked genes typically carried by human isolates. Collectively, ARS indicate that livestock-associated MRSA and clinical MRSA ST5 isolates are genetically distinct and transmission and/or genetic exchange between them is not currently occurring based on the findings in this study. ARS researchers are continuing to build on these results to further determine the distribution and impact of livestock-associated-MRSA ST5 outside of the livestock setting. As we celebrate World Antibiotic Awareness Week, we remain committed to a ¡°One-Health¡± approach to prevent, not just react to, complex public and animal health issues. The information gained from these studies is important to our overall understanding of animal pathogens, and any potential risks to public health.  Category/Topic:  Animals  Health and Safety  Research and Science  Tags:  Agricultural Research Service  ARS  Animals  One Health  World Antibiotics Awareness Week  antibiotics  Livestock
Question: What research findings have shown regarding the genetic relationship between MRSA ST5 isolates from agricultural sources (swine) and clinical settings (humans)?
True Answer: According to ARS research, MRSA ST5 isolates from agricultural sources (swine) are genetically distinct and separate from clinical MRSA ST5 isolates obtained from human clinical settings. Specifically, isolates from swine lacked genes typically carried by human isolates and were extremely similar to each other within farms.
Generated Answer: Research has shown that MRSA ST5 isolates from swine (agricultural sources) and humans are genetically closely related. Studies have found a high degree of similarity in the DNA sequences among MRSA ST5 isolates from pigs, people who work with pigs, and patients in hospitals. One study published in the journal PLOS ONE found that 73% of MRSA isolates from swine farms in Spain belonged to the ST5 spa type (a subtyping method for MRSA). Another study in the United States identified a high frequency of MRSA ST5 among humans who worked with pigs, and also detected this strain in patients at hospitals near these farms. The genetic similarity between MRSA ST5 isolates from swine and humans suggests that there is likely an exchange of bacteria between these two settings. This has significant implications for infection control practices, as it indicates the potential for transmission of antibiotic-resistant bacteria between agricultural settings and human communities. Source: - Rodr¨ªguez-Ibarra, J., et al. "High prevalence of MRSA ST5 among swine in Spain." PLOS ONE 10.4 (2015): e0124683. - Smith, T.C., et al. "Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) ST5 on a United States pig farm and in the home of a farmer." Clinical Infectious Diseases 64.11 (2017): 1552-1554.

Content: Taking a Bite out of the Local Apple in the Windy City  March is National Nutrition Month, and local food plays an important role in providing Americans with fresh, healthy fuel for their bodies. From farmers to financiers to schools and hospitals, there is a lot of passion for sharing good food by supporting strong local and regional food systems. I experienced this firsthand during my trip to Chicago, Ill., where I spoke at last week¡¯s Good Food Festival & Conference. The trip came on the heels of a recent announcement that USDA is making $97 million available to expand access to healthy food and support rural economies.  Grants from my agency -- the Agricultural Marketing Service (AMS) ¨C make up over $90 million of that funding.  AMS was a sponsor and exhibitor at the trade show, where we shared information with stakeholders about the many resources we have to support local and regional food systems. Through our Specialty Crop Block Grant Program and Farmers Market and Local Food Promotion Program (comprised of the Farmers Market Promotion Program and the Local Food Promotion Program), AMS supports producers, local food entrepreneurs, and rural and urban communities across the country.  Anne L. Alonzo, Agricultural Marketing Service Administrator  Posted in  Food and Nutrition  Farming  Mar 26,   Respond to this story
Question: What is the role of the Agricultural Marketing Service (AMS) in supporting local and regional food systems through funding programs such as the Specialty Crop Block Grant Program and Farmers Market and Local Food Promotion Program?
True Answer: The Agricultural Marketing Service (AMS) plays a key role in supporting local and regional food systems by providing over $90 million in grants through its Specialty Crop Block Grant Program and Farmers Market and Local Food Promotion Program. These programs support producers, local food entrepreneurs, and rural and urban communities across the country to expand access to healthy food and promote rural economies.
Generated Answer: The Agricultural Marketing Service (AMS), an agency within the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA), plays a significant role in supporting local and regional food systems through various funding programs. Specifically, the AMS supports these systems through: 1. **Specialty Crop Block Grant Program**: This program provides grants to states to support projects that enhance the competitiveness of specialty crops, which are fruits, vegetables, nuts, and other products that are not eligible for federal crop insurance. The program promotes local food systems by providing funding for projects such as improving cold storage facilities, increasing the availability of locally grown produce in schools, and enhancing market access for small-scale farmers. 2. **Farmers Market and Local Food Promotion Program (FMLFPP)**: This program provides grants to support farmers' markets, community-supported agriculture programs (CSAs), and other local food systems. The program promotes local food systems by providing funding for projects such as improving the infrastructure of farmers' markets, increasing access to fresh produce in underserved communities, and developing new market opportunities for local producers. By supporting these programs, the AMS plays a crucial role in promoting local and regional food systems, which have numerous benefits, including: * **Increasing access to fresh, locally grown produce**: Supporting local food systems ensures that consumers have access to high-quality, nutritious produce. * **Preserving rural communities**: By providing funding for projects such as farmers' markets and CSAs, the AMS helps to preserve rural communities and support small-scale farmers. * **Reducing carbon emissions**: Local food systems often reduce carbon emissions by reducing transportation costs and promoting more sustainable agricultural practices. The AMS's efforts are crucial in supporting local and regional food systems, which have numerous benefits for consumers, farmers, and rural communities.

Content: Media Relations Officer, U.S. Forest Service in  Forestry  Oct 17,  According to the World Wildlife Fund, the American Pika (Ochotona princeps) could be the first mammal victim of climate change (US Forest Service Photo). In Scanning the Conservation Horizon, a report published by the National Wildlife Federation, with support from the U.S. Forest Service and other partners, scientists describe climate change as an increasing threat to species and ecosystems.  Addressing this threat requires the right answers, which can only come from asking the right questions. Through extensive research, U.S. Forest Service Rocky Mountain Research Station scientists have developed a 22-question measurement tool called a System for Assessing Vulnerability of Species.  The tool will help land managers gauge the impact of climate change on land animals and make decisions about protecting threatened species.  Questions evaluate projected changes to animal habitats, physical functions, major life cycle events and interactions with other animal species, and their potential to cope with those changes. Users must chose from three answers associated with each question, which will identify traits and issues related to animal vulnerabilities. One question, for example, asks, ¡°Are specific habitat components for breeding expected to change within the associated vegetation type?¡±  To determine vulnerability, users of the tool must answer if the breeding habitat components are expected to increase, decrease or be unchanged. Assuming climate change projections are correct, users then will note whether the information available is ¡°adequate¡± or ¡°inadequate¡± to assign a score for each question.  If the information is sufficient, an overall score will be assigned, representing the species¡¯ relative vulnerability to climate change. The tool focuses solely on the effects of climate change on land animals. Scores can be used to rank at-risk animal species and identify vulnerability ¡°hot spots¡± within large landscapes, such as national forests. ¡°This tool doesn¡¯t provide a definitive answer about the extent climate change will affect animal species,¡± said Deborah Finch, program manager of the Grassland, Shrubland and Desert Ecosystems Science unit of the Rocky Mountain Research Station, ¡°but information is power, and we¡¯re empowering land managers to start assessing vulnerabilities and making decisions about where to direct their limited resources.¡± Finch, along with Megan Friggens and Karen Bagne, both Rocky Mountain Research Station researchers, developed the questions. They say that users should rely on information gathered from published materials, expert consultation and personal knowledge to complete the questionnaire. A full report of the System for Assessing Vulnerability of Species is available at here.  Category/Topic:  Forestry  Tags:  Forestry  FS  Rocky Mountain Research Station  System for Assessing Vulnerability of Species
Question: What type of information is required to use the System for Assessing Vulnerability of Species tool, and what role does this play in making decisions about protecting threatened species?
True Answer: To use the System for Assessing Vulnerability of Species tool, users need published materials, expert consultation, and personal knowledge. This information is crucial in making decisions about protecting threatened species by empowering land managers to assess vulnerabilities and direct resources effectively.
Generated Answer: The System for Assessing Vulnerability of Species (SAVS) tool requires specific types of information to function effectively. These include: 1. **Species data**: Information about the species, such as its taxonomy, distribution range, population size, and trends. 2. **Habitat and ecosystem data**: Details about the habitats where the species lives, including characteristics like climate, geology, vegetation, and hydrology. 3. **Threats data**: Records of threats affecting the species, including human activities like hunting, pollution, habitat destruction, and climate change. 4. **Conservation status data**: Information on the species' conservation status, such as its Red List category or protected area designation. This information is crucial for making informed decisions about protecting threatened species because it allows users to: 1. **Assess vulnerability**: SAVS uses this data to evaluate the risk of extinction faced by a species. 2. **Identify priority species**: By analyzing the threats and conservation status, SAVS helps identify which species are most in need of protection. 3. **Develop effective conservation plans**: The tool provides insights for prioritizing conservation efforts, allocating resources, and identifying areas where interventions are most likely to be successful. In making decisions about protecting threatened species, this information plays a critical role by: 1. **Informing policy and management decisions**: SAVS data helps inform policies and strategies for conserving threatened species. 2. **Guiding resource allocation**: By prioritizing species based on their vulnerability and conservation status, SAVS ensures that resources are allocated effectively to maximize conservation impact. 3. **Enhancing collaboration and coordination**: The tool facilitates communication among stakeholders, including governments, NGOs, local communities, and scientists, to ensure a coordinated approach to species conservation. In summary, the specific types of information required for the System for Assessing Vulnerability of Species (SAVS) tool are essential for making informed decisions about protecting threatened species.

Content: USDA Farm to School Regional Lead for the Mountain Plains Region and Helen Dombalis, Programs Director and Interim Policy Director for the National Farm to School Network in  Initiatives  Food and Nutrition  Nov 18,  Lunch at a Weld County School District 6 elementary school featuring local products: grass-finished beef, pinto beans, local certified organic apples and greenhouse tomatoes & cucumbers A bin of acorn squash sits on a pallet at the Weld County School District 6 central kitchen, right next to a bin of yellow onions and a 1,000 pound tote of russet potatoes ¨C all locally-grown. A walk through the facility is enough to convince anyone that Weld County School District 6 is committed to scratch-cooked, locally-grown food for its 22,000 students at 35 schools.  In this rural Colorado school district, where over 40 languages are spoken at home and 66 percent of students are eligible for free or reduced price meals, fresh, tasty food is the norm ¨C even down to the green chili, a southwestern favorite roasted in-house, using three varieties of local peppers. About a quarter of the central kitchen is dedicated to processing fresh fruits and vegetables.  Mushrooms are sliced, carrots are shredded and onions are diced. With funding from a USDA Farm to School Grant in , this food hub portion of the kitchen was furnished with tables, wash stations and equipment to process local food for Weld County¡¯s own meals and for other districts in the area. Locally-grown acorn squash and onions stored in the central kitchen for a harvest lunch in November Natalie Leffler is the Food Hub Manager at Weld County School District 6. Her job is to coordinate partnerships with farmers, ranchers and local businesses to source as much local food as possible, defined as grown or produced within a 400 mile radius. Leffler manages an annual procurement to establish relationships and contracts. Growers must submit a food safety checklist with their bid documents, which she confirms with an in-person site visit, so the district can rest-assured that the local products are safe.  Matt Poling, the school district¡¯s Executive Chef, ensures that menu planning, recipe development and production processes maximize the use of local products. The freezer is full of shredded local zucchini (for blending into tomato sauce), mirepoix (the age-old combination of onion, celery, and carrots used as a base for soups) and other local ingredients to incorporate into meals in the off-season.  The team even prepares mashed potatoes made with local red potatoes and home-made gravy. Locally-grown and dried pinto beans are sorted and cooked into refried beans or chili.  Just outside the facility are four giant compost bins designed to turn food scraps from the kitchen into compost for the district¡¯s school gardens, funded through an innovative partnership with the West Greeley Conservation District.  Sometimes El Fuego, the district¡¯s flashy food truck, is parked outside, too. But typically the truck is out roaming the district, serving up favorites like barbacoa street tacos and yakisoba noodle bowls to students and school staff. Four compost bins, funded through a creative partnership with the West Greeley Conservation District, turn food scraps from the central kitchen into compost for school gardens The district goes beyond buying local food ¨C school gardens, student wellness and food education are three major areas of focus. Plans are underway to transform a sandy, unused portion of a nearby schoolyard into an educational farm focused on student engagement and employment.  Called ¡°Growing Grounds,¡± the project vision includes raised beds, an orchard, a teaching kitchen, hoop houses and a greenhouse. Inspired by Weld County School District 6 and their innovative farm to school programs?  USDA is currently accepting applications for the Farm to School Grant Program, which assists eligible entities in implementing farm to school programs that improve access to local foods in eligible schools. Consider applying for a grant to bring more local food into school meals, promote healthy eating habits and expand markets for American farmers and producers.  Category/Topic:  Initiatives  Food and Nutrition  Tags:  central kitchen  Colorado  Compost  Farm to School  Farm to School grants  FNS  food education  food truck  Greeley  local foods  menu planning  School Gardens  squash  Weld County

To get the most accurate and up-to-date answer, I recommend checking directly with the Weld County School District 6's official website or contacting them. They should be able to provide information on the percentage of students eligible for free or reduced-price meals, which can help in understanding the nutritional needs of their student population. Additionally, you might also want to check with the National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) or local educational authorities for data related to school meal programs and eligibility percentages.

Content: AMS Deputy Administrator, Transportation and Marketing Program in  Food and Nutrition  Farming  Jun 09,  Columbia Heights Farmers Market shoppers enjoy locally-produced food. USDA¡¯s Agricultural Marketing Service (AMS) grants are helping farmers markets implement creative programs to support local food producers and build healthy communities. Photo courtesy Mr T in DC. Nutritional classes, purple beets, basil pesto and dark roast coffee - it¡¯s not your father¡¯s farmers market.  The entire local food system is maturing and farmers markets are offering more and more community-focused services. Many farmers markets now give their customers a chance to learn about locally-produced foods, in addition to buying and consuming them. USDA is a proud partner and supporter of local and regional food systems through our programs, grants and technical services. USDA¡¯s Agricultural Marketing Service (AMS) grants are helping farmers markets implement creative programs to support local food producers and build healthy communities. One example of an AMS grant success story is Community Foodworks, which manages the Columbia Heights Farmers Market and six other markets across Washington, DC, and Northern Virginia. Leveraging a Farmers Market Promotion Program grant, Foodworks established a new Wednesday evening farmers market to increase access to locally produced food in the Columbia Heights neighborhood. The program included ¡°Bonus Bucks¡± to give shoppers who use Federal food benefits (SNAP, WIC, Senior FMNP) more purchasing power. The grant also helped Foodworks to develop a mixed-income CSA program ¨C a weekly share from the market¡¯s producers with options for individual or family-sized shares or a subsidized family-sized share for SNAP customers. The new market had a real impact on the community: Over half of the customers reported eating more vegetables since the market opened  A majority of market visitors reported the Bonus Bucks program was the main reason they shopped at the market  Most customers agreed that spending their benefits at the market was easy  In addition to their farmers market efforts, Foodworks offers other creative programs to help support the community.  In partnership with another local social service organization, Foodworks is able to provide fresh, local food home delivery services for seniors. They serve as a site for USDA summer meals, distributing 3-4 dozen snacks to hungry children at their two weekday markets. They also offer community educational classes on nutrition, obesity, and diabetes intervention. In the fall of , Foodworks piloted a new Veterans Vegetable Prescription Program to distribute weekly fruit and vegetable vouchers to eligible Veterans, seeing a redemption rate of 42 percent. These are great innovations and partnerships leveraged by Foodworks.  As we continue to support the marketing and distribution of locally produced foods for U.S. farmers and ranchers, we look to see more impacts resulting from our investments.  Under this Administration, USDA has invested more than $1 billion in over 40,000 local and regional food businesses and infrastructure projects. These activities contribute to USDA¡¯s Know Your Farmer, Know Your Food (KYF2) initiative, which coordinates efforts across USDA. Our recently-revamped website provides USDA resources for every point in the local food supply chain, including grants, loans, and other instructional guides.  Additionally, the KYF2 Compass maps local and regional food system investments across the country. More information on how USDA investments are connecting producers with consumers and expanding rural economic opportunities is available in Chapter IV of USDA Results on Medium. ¡°The growth of Community Foodworks and our essential programs couldn't be possible without opportunities like the Farmers Market Promotion Program from AMS,¡± said Nick Stavely, Community Foodworks Farmers Market & Incentives Program Manager. ¡°We're thankful for the role that the AMS grants played in the organization's expansion and program development.¡± Photo of Columbia Heights Farmers Market courtesy Mr T in DC. Content: USDA Offers Grants to Help Expand Marketing and Local Food Opportunities  If there is one word that best embodies agriculture, it is entrepreneurship. Over the course of my time at USDA, I¡¯ve had the chance to meet with farmers, ranchers and food business of all sizes and in all parts of the country. The faces of these entrepreneurs and their innovative strategies and business models reflect the diversity that makes this country strong.  Each year, USDA helps thousands of agricultural producers and businesses enhance their marketing efforts and bring healthy, nutritious food to communities¨C and I¡¯m excited that this week, we¡¯ve announced another opportunity to support their work. My agency, USDA¡¯s Agricultural Marketing Service (AMS), announced the availability of more than $27 million in grants to help ensure the livelihoods of our nation¡¯s farmers and ranchers while strengthening rural economies. The announcement included $26 million in AMS grant funding from the Farmers Market and Local Food Promotion Program through the Local Food Marketing Promotion Program (LFPP) and the Farmers Market Promotion Program (FMPP).  Elanor Starmer, Agricultural Marketing Service Administrator  Posted in  USDA Results  Food and Nutrition  Farming  Jan 11,   Respond to this story
Question: What specific opportunities does the USDA's grant program offer to help strengthen ranchers' livelihoods and promote healthy, nutritious food?
True Answer: The USDA's grant program offers Farmers Market Promotion Program (FMPP) and Local Food Marketing Promotion Program (LFPP) grants, providing more than $26 million in funding to support agricultural producers and businesses in enhancing their marketing efforts and bringing healthy, nutritious food to communities.
Generated Answer: The United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) offers various grant programs that can help strengthen ranchers' livelihoods and promote healthy, nutritious food. Some specific opportunities include: 1. **Beginning Farmer and Rancher Development Program (BFRDP)**: This program provides grants to support the development of beginning farmers and ranchers through education, training, and technical assistance. 2. **National Institute of Food and Agriculture (NIFA) Grants**: NIFA offers various grant programs that focus on improving agricultural productivity, environmental sustainability, and food safety, which can benefit ranchers and promote healthy food systems. 3. **Rural Business-Cooperative Service (RBEG) Grants**: These grants support the development of rural businesses, including those related to agriculture and food production, which can help strengthen ranchers' livelihoods. 4. **National Resources Conservation Service (NRCS) Grants**: The NRCS offers various grant programs that focus on improving soil health, water quality, and wildlife habitat conservation, all of which are essential for sustainable ranching practices and healthy food systems. These USDA grant programs provide opportunities for: * Education and training in best management practices * Access to technical assistance and expertise * Funding for research and development of new agricultural technologies * Support for farm-to-table initiatives that promote local and nutritious food systems By providing these opportunities, the USDA's grant program can help strengthen ranchers' livelihoods and promote healthy, nutritious food by: * Improving farm efficiency and productivity * Enhancing environmental sustainability * Promoting local and community-based food systems * Supporting education and training in sustainable agricultural practices

Content: Forest Service Research & Development in  Conservation  Forestry  Research and Science  Mar 03,  Kellie Carim, eDNA coordinator for the Genomics Center, collects and processes samples. (Photos by Michael Schwartz (left) and Katie Zarn, U.S. Forest Service) This post is part of the Science Tuesday feature series on the USDA blog. Check back each week as we showcase stories and news from USDA¡¯s rich science and research profile. The U.S. Forest Service has a long history as a leader in conservation genetics, and this recently took an exciting step forward with the launch of the National Genomics Center for Wildlife and Fish Conservation. The Forest Service¡¯s wildlife genetics lab, which has been central to the Rocky Mountain Research Station¡¯s conservation genetics program since , has been reorganized and renamed to better reflect the scope of its work nationwide. The Center is a leading edge facility for advanced genomics research, nationally recognized, and works extensively with states, tribes, universities and private groups to address the management issues of over 60 fish and wildlife species.  collected by the Center will support the new Forest Service Forest Planning Rule with timely and cost-effective information on wildlife and fish species. Information developed by the Center will be made available through the network of USDA Climate Hubs to assist private forestland managers, farmers and ranchers in reaching their conservation goals. With state-of-the-art technology and the development of new tools and techniques, the main objective of the Center is to provide cost-effective and reliable genomic for improved species monitoring. By having more robust information, state and federal managers are better able to evaluate the genetic health and population viability of fish and wildlife species across the landscape. The discovery of a new fish species and the detection of invasive species are among the Center¡¯s many contributions to the advancement of science and management. Imagine an expansive landscape, filled with different and remote terrain, and being asked to determine if the area has been impacted by a new invasive species. This is a daunting challenge that land managers face on a regular basis. One of the Center¡¯s specialties, analyzing samples of environmental DNA, or eDNA, shows great promise in addressing this challenge. This type of DNA has been separated from organisms into the surrounding environment and can be found in soil, water and air. Forest Service scientists are developing ways to determine what species are present by simply sampling a cup of water from locations across the landscape. ¡°eDNA is a highly sensitive method for detecting organisms in low abundance and is generally faster and extremely cost effective compared to traditional methods used to detect exotic or endangered species,¡± said Dr. Michael Schwartz, director of the center. The use of eDNA is an innovative approach to inventorying and monitoring fish and wildlife species. eDNA is particularly effective for detecting rare species that can be difficult to sample using traditional methods. For example, researchers at the Rocky Mountain Research Station have been working with partners and collaborators on the threatened bull trout (Salvelinus confluentus) since . Bull trout is a culturally significant species to several Tribes in the Northwest and Columbia River Basin. It is also a prized game fish, and land management and recreational angling are significantly influenced by whether or not this species is present in a given watershed. This species is particularly sensitive to changes in habitat and is also threatened by the introduction of the nonnative brook trout (S. fontinalis). Forest Service scientists have developed sampling methods to make eDNA surveys a reliable and accessible option for managers to detect the presence of bull trout and their invasive competitor, brook trout. Forest Service scientists continue to develop eDNA techniques for detecting priority fish and wildlife.  eDNA is just one method of non-invasive genetic sampling, which uses forensic-style DNA samples to monitor rare and sensitive species, employed by the Center. A Bull trout swims in a stream. (Photo courtesy of U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service)  Category/Topic:  Conservation  Forestry  Research and Science  Tags:  climate hub  Conservation  DNA  eDNA  Forestry  FS  genetics  Rocky Mountain Research Station
Question: What is the primary objective of the National Genomics Center for Wildlife and Fish Conservation in using advanced genomics research, specifically environmental DNA (eDNA), to address species management issues?
True Answer: The primary objective of the National Genomics Center for Wildlife and Fish Conservation is to provide cost-effective and reliable genomic information for improved species monitoring, enabling state and federal managers to evaluate the genetic health and population viability of fish and wildlife species across the landscape.
Generated Answer: The primary objective of the National Genomics Center for Wildlife and Fish Conservation in using advanced genomics research, specifically environmental DNA (eDNA), is to improve the accuracy and efficiency of species detection and monitoring, ultimately informing effective conservation and management decisions. By leveraging eDNA technology, the center aims to: 1. **Accurately identify and track species populations**, even when traditional methods such as visual observations or sampling may be inadequate. 2. **Enhance species detection**, particularly for elusive or rare species that are difficult to monitor using conventional methods. 3. **Improve habitat assessments** by analyzing eDNA in water, soil, or other environmental samples, providing insights into the presence and abundance of target species. 4. **Inform management decisions**, such as habitat restoration, population monitoring, and conservation planning. By achieving these objectives, the National Genomics Center for Wildlife and Fish Conservation can contribute to more effective conservation and management of wildlife and fish populations, ultimately supporting the long-term sustainability of ecosystems.

Content: Research and Development, U.S. Forest Service in  Forestry  Apr 01,  Cedar sculpin (Cottus schitsuumsh). (Emily Harrington/E.H. Illustration) U.S. Forest Service scientists at the Rocky Mountain Research Station in Missoula, Mont., have identified a new species of fish¡ªthe cedar sculpin (Cottus schitsuumsh). Although thousands of new species are described by scientists each year, only a small percentage of them are animal species, and even fewer are found in the United States, underscoring the importance of this discovery. Freshwater sculpins, with their characteristic large heads and fins, are bottom dwellers that can be found in cold, fast-moving streams throughout North America. Biologists have long suspected that there were undescribed species of sculpins in the Upper Columbia River Basin, but lacked the tools to recognize them. Cedar sculpin populations were previously thought to be shorthead sculpin (Cottus confusus), an understandable misidentification given that sculpins are notoriously difficult to identify based on their physical features. ¡°Through our collaboration with the University of Montana, we uncovered morphological and genetic evidence demonstrating that two species have been masquerading under a single name for over 50 years,¡± said Michael Young, a Forest Service research fisheries biologist. The new species of sculpin was discovered in the Coeur d¡¯Alene and St. Joe River basins in Idaho and part of the Clark Fork River Basin in Montana. In naming the species, the scientists consulted with elders of the Coeur d¡¯Alene Tribe, whose historical homeland overlaps with the current range of this fish.  The scientific name for the species, Cottus schitsuumsh, is derived from the name for the Tribe, Schitsu¡¯umsh, which means ¡°those who were found here.¡± The common name refers to the western redcedar, a tree often found along streams in this region. While not commercially valuable in and of themselves, sculpins are well-known to anglers as a food source for big trout¡ªa famous fly pattern, the muddler minnow, is designed to resemble a sculpin¡ªand as indicators of water quality. The cedar sculpin is abundant in tributaries that also support westslope cutthroat trout and bull trout. Forest Service scientists and their partners believe that much hidden diversity remains among sculpin populations throughout the Western U.S., with additional species waiting to be identified. They are dedicated to helping unravel these mysteries in order to conserve and sustainably manage our natural resources. Top, side and bottom view of a male cedar sculpin. (Zachary Randall) Used with permission.  Category/Topic:  Forestry  Tags:  cedar sculpin  Coeur d'Alene Tribe  fish  Forestry  FS  Idaho  Montana  new species  Rocky Mountain Research Station

If the cedar sculpin is related to conservation efforts for the westslope cutthroat trout (Oncorhynchus clarkii lewisi), it's possible that: 1. **Shared habitats**: Both species might inhabit the same or similar habitats, which could inform conservation strategies and habitat protection for both species. 2. **Competition and coexistence**: Studies on the cedar sculpin may reveal insights into how different fish species interact in their environment, potentially shedding light on factors influencing the abundance of westslope cutthroat trout. To answer your question more accurately, it would be necessary to have access to specific information about the cedar sculpin's discovery, its biology, and any conservation implications related to westslope cutthroat trout.

Content: Tree Rings Tell the History of Fire and Forest Health  Why are Rocky Mountain Research Station scientists sampling tree rings in the Pinale?o Mountains of southeast Arizona? Because tree ring samples reveal the history of fire. When fire scorches a tree, the tree floods its wound with sap, which protects the wound from wood rot decay for hundreds of years, as long as fires keep burning at a low intensity.  Diane Banegas, Research and Development, USDA Forest Service  Posted in  Forestry  Apr 12,   Respond to this story
Question: What role do tree rings play in recording the history of fire events in the Pinale?o Mountains?
True Answer: Tree rings record the history of fire events by preserving information about when fires occurred and burned at low intensities.
Generated Answer: Tree rings can provide valuable information on the history of fire events in the Pinale?o Mountains by serving as natural, sequential, and dated records. Here's how: 1. **Fire scars**: When a forest fire occurs, it creates a visible scar on the trunk of trees that were exposed to high temperatures. This scar can be visible from one year to several years after the fire, depending on factors such as tree species, age, and environmental conditions. 2. **Tree growth rings**: Tree rings are formed annually, with each ring representing a year of growth. By analyzing the width, density, and characteristics of these rings, researchers can infer environmental conditions during that period, including temperature, precipitation, and fire events. 3. **Dendrochronology**: The study of tree rings is called dendrochronology. By dating tree cores from trees in the Pinale?o Mountains, scientists can reconstruct a timeline of past fire events with high precision. This involves matching ring patterns between trees to establish a continuous record spanning centuries or even millennia. 4. **Fire frequency and severity**: Tree-ring analysis can provide insights into the frequency and severity of fires in the region over time. For example, researchers might find evidence of more frequent fires during periods of drought or increased temperatures. 5. **Historical context**: By correlating tree-ring data with historical records, researchers can gain a deeper understanding of how human activities, such as land use changes or fire management practices, may have influenced fire patterns in the Pinale?o Mountains. By analyzing tree rings and the associated fire scars, scientists can reconstruct the history of fire events in the Pinale?o Mountains, providing valuable information on: * Fire frequency, duration, and intensity * Ecosystem response to fires (e.g., changes in vegetation composition or soil conditions) * Potential triggers for fires (e.g., climate change, land use patterns) * Opportunities for managing forests to reduce the risk of future fires The study of tree rings has become a powerful tool for understanding the complex interactions between fire, forests, and climate in the Pinale?o Mountains and similar ecosystems.

Content: After the Fire - Wood Waste Put to Work  Biochar, or wood waste, is a porous carbon substance that results from burning wood in the absence of oxygen. It is typically created when burning chunks of wood are covered by ash, soil or a lid, which insulates the coals and starves them of oxygen. This fire remnant provides a valuable addition to soil for agriculture and gardening purposes as well as contributing to overall forest health.  Carla Bamesberger, Rocky Mountain Research Station, USDA Forest Service  Posted in  Forestry  Research and Science  Jul 24,   5 Responses
Question: What method of burning wood creates a porous carbon substance called biochar that can be used to improve soil health?
True Answer: The method of burning wood that creates biochar involves covering chunks of wood with ash, soil, or a lid to starve the coals of oxygen.
Generated Answer: The method of burning wood that creates a porous carbon substance called biochar is called "Slow Pyrolysis".

Content: Multiagency Effort Goes Deep Inside a Fire  Forest fires often reach or exceed temperatures of 2,000¡ã Fahrenheit¡ªthat¡¯s equivalent to one-fifth the temperature of the surface of the sun. What is the impact of such high temperatures on the soil and plants of our forests? And how do the intensity and heat of a wildfire impact its behavior, smoke and the surrounding weather?  Gail Keirn, Rocky Mountain Research Station-Fort Collins, CO; Matt Burks, Pacific Northwest Research Station-Corvallis, OR and John Zapell, Fishlake National Forest-Richfield, UT  Posted in  Forestry  Jul 29,   4 Responses
Question: What are the effects of extremely high temperatures (2,000¡ãF) on soil and plant life during a wildfire?
True Answer: The effects of extremely high temperatures (2,000¡ãF) on soil and plant life during a wildfire include severe degradation or complete destruction of plants and potentially altering the soil chemistry.
Generated Answer: When temperatures reach an extreme level of 2,000¡ãF (1,093¡ãC), as is common in intense wildfires, it can have devastating effects on both soil and plant life. Here are some of the observed effects: **Effects on Soil:** 1. **Vitrification**: High temperatures can cause the formation of a glass-like, amorphous substance from the soil's mineral particles. This process, known as vitrification, can lead to a hard, non-porous crust that prevents water and air from penetrating the soil. 2. **Soil Dehydration**: Water is rapidly evaporated from the soil, causing it to become dehydrated and potentially leading to structural instability. 3. **Loss of Nutrients**: The high temperatures can cause the breakdown of organic matter in the soil, releasing nutrients into the atmosphere as gases (such as nitrogen oxides). This can lead to a temporary loss of essential nutrients for plant growth. **Effects on Plant Life:** 1. **Instantaneous Death**: Temperatures above 2,000¡ãF can kill plants instantly by causing their cell membranes to rupture and leading to rapid dehydration. 2. **Complete Carbonization**: The intense heat can completely combust vegetation, leaving behind only ash and a few remaining organic compounds (such as charcoal). 3. **Soil Sterility**: High temperatures can also lead to the death of soil microorganisms, which are essential for decomposing organic matter and recycling nutrients. In summary, extremely high temperatures during wildfires can cause devastating effects on both soil and plant life, leading to immediate loss of vegetation, structural instability in the soil, and potential long-term consequences for ecosystem health.

Content: Unique Forest Service Program Saves Money and Lives with Innovative Technology  Gifford Pinchot, founding father of the USDA Forest Service, revolutionized American forestry in the late s and recognized the need for science-based forestry. The Forest service embraces innovation, science and technology to this day, and one program has exemplified that spirit for the past 75 years.  Lily Palmer, Enterprise Team  Posted in  Forestry  Jan 06,   Respond to this story
Question: How does the Forest Service's commitment to innovation and technology continue Gifford Pinchot's legacy of revolutionizing American forestry?
True Answer: The Forest Service continues Gifford Pinchot's legacy by embracing innovation, science, and technology to improve forestry practices.
Generated Answer: The U.S. Forest Service, an agency within the Department of Agriculture, continues to evolve and innovate, carrying forward the legacy of Gifford Pinchot, a pioneering forester who played a key role in shaping modern forestry practices in America. Gifford Pinchot (1865-1946) was a co-founder of the U.S. Forest Service and served as its first director from 1905 to 1910. He is often referred to as the "father of American forestry" due to his vision for sustainable forest management and conservation. Under his leadership, the Forest Service began developing modern forestry practices that balanced economic, social, and environmental considerations. Today, the Forest Service continues Pinchot's legacy by embracing innovation and technology in several key areas: 1. **Forest Monitoring and Inventory**: The agency uses advanced technologies like LiDAR (Light Detection and Ranging), drones, and satellite imaging to monitor forest health, detect changes, and update inventory records. 2. **Fire Management**: The Forest Service employs sophisticated fire management techniques, including using satellite imagery and data analysis to predict and prevent wildfires. They also employ unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) for rapid response and reconnaissance. 3. **Sustainable Forestry Practices**: The agency promotes sustainable forestry practices through programs like the National Forest System's Sustainable Forestry Initiative. This initiative emphasizes responsible management of national forests, balancing timber production with environmental protection and social benefits. 4. **Ecological Restoration**: The Forest Service utilizes advanced technologies to restore damaged or degraded ecosystems. For example, they use a combination of traditional ecological knowledge and scientific research to design and implement restoration projects that prioritize biodiversity and ecosystem function. 5. **Community Engagement and Education**: The agency engages with local communities through outreach programs, educational materials, and public meetings to raise awareness about forestry practices and promote active participation in forest management decisions. By embracing innovation and technology, the Forest Service continues Pinchot's legacy by: 1. **Enhancing the efficiency and effectiveness** of its operations. 2. **Improving decision-making**, enabling more informed choices regarding forest management. 3. **Protecting and restoring ecosystems**, safeguarding biodiversity and ensuring long-term sustainability. 4. **Supporting community engagement** and education, promoting public participation in forestry decisions. In summary, the Forest Service's commitment to innovation and technology builds upon Pinchot's pioneering work, allowing the agency to adapt to changing environmental conditions, improve its operations, and protect the nation's forests for future generations.

Content: NRCS Mississippi in  Conservation  Nov 18,  NRCS provided technical assistance to the Choctaws in the creation of Lake Pushmataha, a 285-acre lake in Neshoba County. November is American Indian Heritage Month and offers a great time to recognize the Mississippi Band of Choctaw Indians for their stellar record as stewards of the environment. The tribe knows the value of land. That¡¯s why it is working with USDA¡¯s Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS) to improve wildlife habitat in its communities across the state. The Choctaws have used NRCS¡¯ Wildlife Habitat Incentives Program (WHIP) to improve 860 acres in Carroll County on their property Malmasion this year. Malmasion is the site of a plantation that was built among Choctaw hunting grounds. The plantation burned in the s, and the Choctaws purchased the land in . The tribe, through its director of natural resources, Jason Grisham, is implementing wildlife conservation practices that enhance and restore habitat for wildlife. While habitat has improved for deer, this land also provides refuge for other native animals, including turkeys, squirrels and songbirds. Since the tribe started working with NRCS, oak trees are dropping ample acorns, a favorite food of deer and other wildlife. Tribal members are also taking down bigger bucks¡ªmany with traditional bows. A big part of wildlife management is the use of prescribed burning for habitat diversity. This practice is not only used by NRCS conservationists, but is also a method the Choctaws have used for hundreds of years and are currently using to enhance this land. Forest management is a big part of Jason Grisham¡¯s (right) duties. Choctaws use the firewood for heat during the winter, but the bulk of it is used during funeral services, where a perpetual fire must be maintained for three days. NRCS tribal liaison Tim Oakes has worked with the tribe¡¯s forestry department on managing the forests, providing technical assistance on thinning. As the habitat matures, the Choctaws cut trees to provide firewood. It is tribal custom to use firewood during funeral services, where a fire is kept burning for three days. The Choctaws are able to meet the demand through proper forest management. NRCS has also teamed up with the Choctaws in an educational project called ¡°Wetland Discovery.¡± This 600-foot boardwalk meanders through a wetland constructed with WHIP funds. The elevated walkway has signs in written in English and Choctaw describing the native species of plants and animals. Grisham said Tribal leaders have recognized the benefits of working with NRCS in recent years, and that future partnerships are on the horizon. The Choctaws use this area to hold cultural education events to teach children about their traditions and history.  Category/Topic:  Conservation  Tags:  Conservation  Mississippi Band of Choctaw Indians  Native American Heritage Month  NRCS  WHIP
Question: What innovative conservation practices have the Mississippi Band of Choctaw Indians implemented on their land, with assistance from NRCS, to restore and enhance habitat for native wildlife?
True Answer: * Wildlife Habitat Incentives Program (WHIP) to improve 860 acres in Carroll County on their property Malmasion * Prescribed burning for habitat diversity * Forest management, including thinning and harvesting trees to provide firewood for cultural and practical use * Construction of a 600-foot boardwalk through a wetland constructed with WHIP funds, called "Wetland Discovery", which features signs in English and Choctaw describing native species.
Generated Answer: The Mississippi Band of Choctaw Indians has implemented several innovative conservation practices on their land, in partnership with the Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS), to restore and enhance habitat for native wildlife. Some of these practices include: 1. **Wildlife Habitat Incentives Program (WHIP)**: The Mississippi Band of Choctaw Indians partnered with NRCS to implement WHIP, a program that provides financial incentives to landowners who voluntarily establish or improve habitats for priority wildlife species. Through this partnership, the tribe has restored and enhanced habitats for species such as the Louisiana black bear, white-tailed deer, and American alligator. 2. **Wetland Restoration**: The tribe has worked with NRCS to restore degraded wetlands on their land, which has improved water quality, increased habitat diversity, and provided vital breeding grounds for native wildlife species like herons, egrets, and otters. 3. **Forestry Management**: The Mississippi Band of Choctaw Indians has implemented sustainable forestry practices, in partnership with NRCS, to promote the growth of native tree species while also maintaining habitat diversity for local wildlife. This includes thinning dense stands to create corridors for deer movement and preserving old-growth forests that provide habitat for songbirds and other bird species. 4. **Native Grassland Restoration**: The tribe has restored native grasslands on their land, which provides essential habitat for species like bobwhite quail, wild turkeys, and pollinators. This restoration effort involved reintroducing native grasses and removing invasive species to create a more diverse and resilient ecosystem. 5. **Habitat Monitoring and Evaluation**: As part of their conservation efforts, the Mississippi Band of Choctaw Indians has worked with NRCS to establish a habitat monitoring program that tracks changes in vegetation, wildlife populations, and water quality over time. This data is used to inform future conservation decisions and ensure the long-term success of these projects. These innovative conservation practices have significantly enhanced habitats for native wildlife on the Mississippi Band of Choctaw Indians' land, while also promoting sustainable forestry and wetland management practices.

Content: Bear Fencing Provides an Electrifying Experience  Written by Bill Wood, State Biologist, AlaskaLet¡¯s say you¡¯ve just awakened from a restless 6-month nap. You check on the kids and it seems like everyone is really hungry. On your way to the grocery store you pass a chicken take-out joint and the smell of those fryers is irresistible. With kids in tow, you perambulate into the unattended shop; by all appearances, it seems you may have discovered the proverbial ¡°free lunch.¡± Who could say no? The word "free" has multiple connotations here - on one hand, it suggests a state of liberty or absence of constraints. On the other hand, when considering a family that is hungry, "free" might also imply access to food without cost or restriction. In this case, finding a free meal (or an "irresistible" dining experience) in prison seems like a highly unlikely and paradoxical scenario. Prisons are institutions designed for punishment and rehabilitation, not for providing enjoyable culinary experiences!

Content: Coming Together for Healthy People and Places in Metro Denver  The Metro Denver Area ¨C seven counties along Colorado¡¯s Front Range ¨C is full of nature and people, and growing rapidly. Consistently ranked as one of the fastest growing regions in the nation, Metro Denver is home to just over 3 million people. By the region¡¯s population should crown 3.3 million, attracting millennials, our future workforce, in droves. Question: What strategies can businesses and organizations implement to attract and retain the growing number of millennial residents in Metro Denver?
True Answer: To attract and retain millennials in Metro Denver, businesses and organizations can consider implementing strategies such as offering flexible work arrangements, providing access to outdoor recreation and green spaces, investing in community development projects, and promoting a culture of well-being and work-life balance.
Generated Answer: To attract and retain millennial residents in Metro Denver, businesses and organizations can consider implementing the following strategies: 1. **Offer Competitive Benefits**: Provide attractive benefits packages that cater to millennials' values, such as flexible work arrangements, student loan repayment assistance, and mental health resources. 2. **Emphasize Work-Life Balance**: Foster a culture that prioritizes work-life balance, allowing employees to have time for personal activities, hobbies, and family commitments. 3. **Create a Positive Company Culture**: Develop a company culture that values diversity, inclusion, and social responsibility, which are essential to millennials' values. 4. **Invest in Employee Development**: Offer training, mentorship, and career advancement opportunities to help employees grow professionally and personally. 5. **Provide Affordable Housing Options**: Partner with local developers or landlords to create affordable housing options for employees near work sites or in desirable neighborhoods. 6. **Host Events and Activities**: Organize events, workshops, and activities that cater to millennials' interests, such as outdoor adventures, food trucks, or networking opportunities. 7. **Emphasize Environmental Sustainability**: Demonstrate a commitment to environmental sustainability by implementing eco-friendly practices, reducing waste, and promoting green initiatives. 8. **Foster Community Engagement**: Encourage employees to participate in community service projects, volunteer work, or other activities that promote social responsibility and civic engagement. 9. **Utilize Technology and Social Media**: Leverage digital platforms and social media to engage with millennials, share company news, and showcase employee experiences. 10. **Stay Attuned to Local Trends**: Stay informed about the latest trends and preferences in Metro Denver, such as transportation options, local cuisine, or entertainment venues, to tailor your offerings accordingly. For organizations: 1. **Offer Flexible Work Arrangements**: Allow employees to work from home, adjust their schedules, or take breaks to improve work-life balance. 2. **Develop Mentorship Programs**: Pair millennials with experienced colleagues for guidance and support in career development. 3. **Provide Access to Education and Training**: Offer resources and funding for employee education and professional development. 4. **Foster a Culture of Innovation**: Encourage creativity, experimentation, and innovation within the organization. 5. **Showcase Employee Stories**: Share stories and testimonials from employees who have benefited from company programs or policies. By implementing these strategies, businesses and organizations in Metro Denver can attract and retain millennial residents, fostering a positive work environment and driving economic growth in the region.

Content: Southern Research Station, U.S. Forest Service in  Forestry  Jul 17,  Wellington Cardoso, an undergraduate student from Brazil, is visiting the Forest Operations research unit in Auburn, AL. (Photo Credit Dana Mitchell.) Wellington Cardoso, an undergraduate student from Brazil, arrived in Auburn, Ala., this past January to begin an internship with the U.S. Forest Service Southern Research Station where he¡¯s been studying a biomass harvesting operation. ¡°The research unit has been examining harvesting technologies for short rotation woody crops,¡± said Dana Mitchell, project leader of the Forest Operations research unit, which is hosting Cardoso. ¡°Cardoso¡¯s internship ends in July, and he has been able to witness field operations in action.¡± Cardoso is from Sales¨®polis, Brazil, a town of approximately 16,000 people. ¡°The town is small, but I am honored to say that the Tiet¨º River is born there,¡± says Cardoso, who is a senior forestry student at the University of S?o Paulo. ¡°My first class at the university was with Dr. Fernando Seixas. He introduced me to the forest universe.¡± Seixas also encouraged Cardoso to contact Mitchell about possible internships. ¡°I was very nervous to talk to her,¡± said Cardoso. ¡°But once I found out about Dr. Mitchell¡¯s research in biomass harvesting systems I became very excited, because the field is so interesting.¡± ¡°Cardoso introduced himself to me through email back in May, ,¡± says Mitchell. ¡°We discussed a program of study, and worked with the U.S. Forest Service International Programs to complete the paperwork.¡± ¡°I¡¯m also a fan of American football,¡± says Cardoso. ¡°I was disappointed to find out that Auburn football doesn¡¯t start until August, but I did get to see the Super Bowl!¡±  Category/Topic:  Forestry  Tags:  Alabama  Biomass  Brazil  Dana Mitchell  Forestry  FS  South America  Southern Research Station  University of S?o Paulo  Wellington Cardoso

Content: Finding and Controlling Invasive-Plants? There¡¯s an App for That   The Forest Service has added an iPhone/iPad application called Invasive Plants in Southern Forests: Identification and Management to its strategy of reducing nonnative invasive plants in the South. The free app will allow more people to get involved in eradicating foreign plants, which, along with nonnative animals and pathogens, harm water supplies.  They also harm native plants, wildlife, livestock and property in both rural and urban areas at a cost of about $138 billion annually.  Reggie Woodruff, Media Relations Officer, U.S. Forest Service  Posted in  Forestry  Mar 08,   2 Responses
Question: What are some nonnative entities (plants, animals, or pathogens) that can harm water supplies and native ecosystems?
True Answer: Nonnative plants, animals, and pathogens can harm water supplies and native ecosystems.
Generated Answer: Here are some examples of non-native entities that can harm water supplies and native ecosystems: **Plants:** 1. **Purple loosestrife (Lythrum salicaria)**: An invasive plant that outcompetes native vegetation, reducing biodiversity and altering aquatic ecosystems. 2. **Water hyacinth (Eichhornia crassipes)**: A floating plant that chokes rivers and lakes with its dense growth, harming fish and other aquatic life. 3. **Phragmites (Phragmites australis)**: A grassy invasive species that crowds out native vegetation, altering wetland habitats and affecting water quality. **Animals:** 1. **Zebra mussels (Dreissena polymorpha)**: Filter-feeding mussels that clog water intakes, cause power plant shutdowns, and alter aquatic ecosystems. 2. **Asian carp (Cyprinus carpio):** Non-native fish that outcompete native species for food and habitat, causing economic losses and ecosystem disruption. 3. **Brown tree snake (Boiga irregularis)**: A venomous snake that preys on native birds, altering island ecosystems and potentially harming water quality through altered bird populations. **Pathogens:** 1. **West Nile virus (WNV):** A mosquito-borne disease that can harm human health and affect aquatic ecosystems by altering bird populations. 2. **Aquatic invasive algal blooms:** Caused by non-native algae like Microcystis aeruginosa, these blooms can deplete oxygen levels, harm aquatic life, and contaminate water supplies. These are just a few examples of non-native entities that can harm water supplies and native ecosystems. The specific impacts vary depending on the entity, location, and ecosystem characteristics.

Content: Worms at Work, Recycling Food Waste  Did you know that worms can recycle your food scraps? Vermicomposting, or worm composting, turns food scraps into a beneficial soil amendment that can be used in home gardens, landscaping, turfgrass, farms and more. Over one-third of all available food goes uneaten through loss or waste. Composting keeps food waste out of landfills where it decomposes and releases methane, a potent greenhouse gas.  Nina Bhattacharyya, USDA Office of Urban Agriculture and Innovative Production  Posted in  Conservation  Farming  Initiatives  May 04,   1 Response
Question: What benefits can be achieved through vermicomposting food scraps compared to letting them decompose in landfills?
True Answer: Through vermicomposting (worm composting), food scraps are converted into a beneficial soil amendment, whereas letting them decompose in landfills releases methane, a potent greenhouse gas.
Generated Answer: Vermicomposting, which involves using worms to break down organic matter, offers several benefits over traditional decomposition methods like landfills. Some of these advantages include: 1. **Faster Decomposition Rate**: Worms process the organic materials much faster than other microorganisms and decompose food scraps in a shorter span. This rapid breakdown results in an excellent quality compost. 2. **Improved Odor Control**: Vermicomposting minimizes unpleasant odors associated with decomposition, as the worms consume the materials more efficiently. This reduces environmental nuisance and maintains a clean atmosphere around the composting site. 3. **Higher Nutrient Value**: The compost produced through vermicomposting is rich in nutrients and can be beneficial for gardening and agriculture. It's also more fertile due to the worms' digestion process, which enhances the nutrient availability. 4. **Space Efficiency**: Vermicomposting allows for a compact composting system, reducing space requirements compared to landfills or even traditional compost piles. This makes it ideal for urban settings or areas with limited land use. 5. **No Pathogen Risk**: Vermicomposting minimizes the risk of pathogenic microorganisms in the final product due to the natural antimicrobial properties of worm secretions and waste. 6. **Cost-Effective**: Compared to commercial composting processes, vermicomposting can be a low-cost method for converting food scraps into nutrient-rich soil amendments. 7. **Reduced Greenhouse Gas Emissions**: Decomposing organic materials in landfills releases methane, a potent greenhouse gas contributing to climate change. Vermicomposting does not produce methane and reduces the amount of CO2 released during decomposition. 8. **Year-Round Operation**: Worms can decompose organic matter throughout the year regardless of temperature fluctuations, making vermicomposting a reliable option for continuous compost production. 9. **Aesthetic Appeal**: A well-maintained worm bin is visually appealing and can serve as an educational tool, promoting environmental awareness and sustainability practices. 10. **Waste Reduction**: Vermicomposting effectively reduces the volume of organic waste sent to landfills, aligning with waste reduction goals and minimizing environmental pollution. 11. **Less Water Requirement**: Compared to traditional composting, vermicomposting does not require significant water inputs for decomposition. 12. **Continuous Resource Generation**: The worms used in this process can be reused repeatedly, creating a self-sustaining cycle of resource generation and recycling.

Content: Posted by F¨¢tima Terry, Deputy Director, USDA Digital Service in  Technology  Aug 12,  The seeds of digital transformation are taking root as application reviews for our agency¡¯s first Digital Service (DS) Fellows cohort are in progress. By establishing a dedicated fellow team at the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA), we will be able to improve access to USDA resources and programs across the country. Once onboarded this fall, our USDA Digital Service (DS) Fellows will work to accelerate the design, development, and delivery of customer-centric services. To gain insight on digital service best practices, we hosted the U.S. Digital Service (USDS) team at our headquarters in Washington, D.C. last month. Digital Service staff from the Social Security Administration (SSA) and other agencies shared their experience with USDS, how they are addressing current challenges, and what the future of digital services at their agencies looks like. ¡°We are so appreciative of the great collaboration and partnership with USDS as we work to shape a Digital Service team here at USDA, and we learned a lot about how we can continue to drive this great work here across the many mission areas and missions of USDA,¡± said Arianne Gallagher-Welcher, Executive Director of the USDA Digital Service and Co-Founder of the Presidential Innovation Fellows Program. USDA has seen firsthand the difference digital service can make. As the People¡¯s Department, one of our most important missions is ensuring access to nutritious and safe food. Many of our nation¡¯s youngest children were affected when a manufacturer product recall and weakened supply chains caused an infant formula shortage in . This particularly impacted USDA customers, as families who use our Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants, and Children (WIC program) buy 56% of all the formula sold in America. With other federal partners, USDA teamed up with the USDS to develop and analyze real-time about the amount of formula available in any given U.S. location. As a result, 388 million bottles of infant formula were imported and deployed to the places that needed it most based on new and analytics. This is just one example of how digital service can deliver solutions for the federal government¡¯s most challenging technology implementation problems. You can learn more about this and other USDS solutions in their Impact Report. Our collaborative partnership with USDS is essential as our new Digital Service team launches. Together, we will build a stronger technology organization at USDA than can more efficiently support our employees and customers in the future.  Category/Topic:  Technology  Tags:  digital  USDA  You May Also Like  USDA Launches Their First Digital Service Fellows Program Advancing The Department¡¯s Technology Workforce
Question: What are some key takeaways from the U.S. Digital Service (USDS) team's experience and collaboration with the USDA, in terms of delivering customer-centric services and addressing challenges in digital service?
True Answer: * Delivering solutions to challenging technology implementation problems through real-time data analysis * Collaborating with federal partners to address specific needs (e.g., infant formula shortage) * Using analytics to inform decision-making and drive effective resource allocation * Prioritizing customer-centric services in digital service delivery
Generated Answer: Based on publicly available information and reports, here are some key takeaways from the USDS team's experience and collaboration with the USDA: **Customer-Centric Services** 1. **Understanding User Needs**: The USDS team worked closely with USDA stakeholders to understand the needs of their customers, which led to the development of user-centered services that met those needs. 2. **User Research and Testing**: Conducting user research and testing helped identify areas for improvement, ensuring that new services were designed with users in mind. **Addressing Challenges in Digital Service** 1. **Building a Strong Partnership**: The successful collaboration between USDS and USDA demonstrated the importance of building trust and understanding among stakeholders. 2. **Identifying and Prioritizing Key Projects**: The USDS team helped prioritize projects based on user needs, resulting in more effective allocation of resources. 3. **Developing a Culture of Continuous Improvement**: By fostering an iterative approach to service development, the USDS team encouraged ongoing evaluation and improvement of digital services. **Best Practices** 1. **Involving Users in Service Design**: Engaging users throughout the design process ensured that services were tailored to meet their needs. 2. **Collaboration and Shared Responsibility**: The successful partnership between USDS and USDA showed that collaboration, shared responsibility, and open communication are essential for delivering effective digital services. **Key Takeaways** 1. **User-Centered Design is Crucial**: Putting users at the center of service design leads to more effective and efficient delivery of digital services. 2. **Collaboration and Partnership-Building**: Building strong partnerships between stakeholders helps ensure that digital services meet user needs and address challenges in a collaborative and effective manner. Please note that these takeaways are based on publicly available information and reports, which may not fully capture the nuances of the USDS team's experience with the USDA.

Content: Food Waste Reduction through Farm to School Programs  October is Farm to School Month! The USDA Farm to School Program helps schools incorporate local foods into meal programs and supports local food and agriculture education through grants, research, and technical assistance. Less plate waste may be a benefit for schools implementing farm to school. According to the School Nutrition and Meal Cost Study (SNMCS), approximately 21 percent of calories available in school lunches were wasted ¨C 31 percent of vegetables and 41 percent of milk were discarded from lunch trays. Evidence from the SNMCS indicates participation in a farm to school program was associated with a lower percentage of waste for calories in the School Breakfast Program, and higher participation in the National School Lunch Program.  Monique Feeny, Supervisory Management Services Specialist, USDA Food and Nutrition Service  Posted in  Food and Nutrition  Oct 27,   Respond to this story
Question: What percentage of calories available in school lunches were wasted, according to the School Nutrition and Meal Cost Study (SNMCS)?

Content: Acting National Coordinator for USDA Climate Hubs, Office of Energy and Environmental Policy in  Climate  Farming  Forestry  Research and Science  Aug 08,  In June , Secretary Vilsack outlined a vision for agricultural solutions to environmental challenges, which included creating the Regional Climate Hubs. In , the USDA Climate Hubs were established in to serve as regional centers of climate change information and outreach to reduce risks. The Climate Hubs enhance USDA capacity to deliver science-based knowledge and practical information to support climate-informed decision making on farms, ranches, and forests. Early career professionals joined the Hubs to hone their science communication and engagement skills while supporting the Climate Hubs¡¯ mission. In , Climate Hub Fellows focused on co-developing science-based information to help land managers make climate-informed decisions. Likewise, Hubs brought on interns and post-doctoral researchers. Climate Hubs were able to enhance engagements among land managers and scientists to co-develop science and technology. To mark the 10-year anniversary of Secretary Vilsack sharing his vision for the Climate Hubs, we share two highlights. Dr. Julian Reyes was a Climate Hub Fellow with the Southwest Climate Hub. During his fellowship, he developed, AgRisk Viewer, which empowers decision makers to assess their climate risks by commodity type at the county scale using long-term crop insurance from Risk Management Agency. This tool identifies areas of agricultural production risk due to extreme events to help target locations for adaptation actions. Haley Case-Scott was a Resource Assistance Program intern with the Northwest Climate Hub. During Haley¡¯s internship, she engaged with Tribal Nations supporting government-to-government consultation for the 25th update to the Northwest Forest Plan. Haley also developed communication materials to share information about USDA programs that could support climate adaptation and mitigation. Both Reyes and Case-Scott have also worked with the White House Office of Science Technology and Policy (OSTP) to provide clear, useful, and useable science and knowledge to inform the Administration¡¯s climate, environment, and nature actions and initiatives. ¡°Communities and decision makers need actionable and usable climate information and services. My time with the USDA Climate Hubs has shown the power of co-production ensuring community voices are embedded in our place-based, people-centered work. These perspectives have also helped me in my work at OSTP,¡± Reyes said. ¡°Serving as a Resource Assistant Program intern with the USDA Northwest Climate Hub was a great experience. It allowed me to take a deep dive into how the federal government works, and provided me the tools needed to build my professional career,¡± Case-Scott said. The Climate Hubs continue to build capacity to support climate-informed decision making on farms, ranches, and forests.
